content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group Inc. OFG, +1.44% said Thursday it'll pay $500 million for Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A.'s BBVA, -1.39% operations in Puerto Rico. The transaction will make Oriental Financial the second-largest bank in Puero Rico. On an adjusted basis, the deal will add 35% to Oriental's 2013 earnings. Oriental plans to book $40 million in one-time charges in connection with the deal.
title: Oriental paying $500 mln for BBVA Puerto Rico unit

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Friday's session are Wyeth, Agilent Technologies Inc. and Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. Campbell Soup Co. CPB, -2.45% is expected to report earnings per share for the second quarter of 63 cents, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial. Goodyear GT, -1.73% is expected to post a fourth-quarter per-share loss of 40 cents. Hormel Foods Corp. HRL, -2.42% is expected to report first-quarter per-share earnings of 54 cents. J. M. Smucker Co. SJM, -3.42% is expected to post third-quarter earnings of 69 cents per share. Sierra Pacific Resources SRP, -0.17% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings per share of 7 cents. Visteon Corp. VC, -1.58% is expected to post a fourth-quarter per-share loss of 81 cents. After Thursday's closing bell, Agilent A, -3.48% said first-quarter net income fell to $150 million, or 36 cents a share, from $2.82 million, or $5.83 a share, during the same period in the prior year that included a benefit of $901 million on the Lumileds sale. See After Hours column. Watch list Allied Waste Industries Inc. AW reported fourth-quarter net income of $9.8 million, or break-even measured in per-share results, down from $66.7 million, or 15 cents a share, a year ago. BJ's Restaurants Inc. BJRI, -2.12% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $2.82 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with $2.32 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same period last year, boosted by higher revenue. The restaurant owner and operator said revenue rose 34% to $65.9 million from $49.3 million, as comparable-restaurant sales increased 5.5%. Bsquare Corp. BSQR, -1.18% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $706,000, or 7 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the company posted a net loss of $246,000, or 3 cents a share. California Pizza Kitchen Inc. CPKI said fourth-quarter net income was $3.73 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with $3.48 million, or 17 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Reporting after the close, the company said revenue was $146 million vs. last year's $125.4 million. Career Education Corp. CECO, -1.90% said fourth-quarter net income fell, as revenue declined, to $20.7 million, or 21.5 cents a share, from $70.3 million, or 70.1 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts had expected per-share income of 37 cents. Chipotle Mexican Grill CMG, -3.70% said more customers eating at its restaurants helped feed fourth-quarter results that were far better than Wall Street's expectations. Denver-based Chipotle -- ending its first fiscal year as a public company -- said it made $10.8 million, or 33 cents a share, for the quarter compared with last year's profit of $4.26 million, or 16 cents a share. Copano Energy LLC CPNO said it has approved a 2-for-1 split of its outstanding units. The additional units will be distributed on March 30 to unit-holders of record as of March 15. Dendrite International Inc. DRTE reported a preliminary fourth-quarter operating loss of about $12.5 million, on revenue of $111.4 million. In the same period last year, the pharmaceutical industry services company posted revenue of $108.4 million. Denny's Corp. DENN, -1.81% said it swung to net income in the fourth-quarter of $2.27 million, or 2 cents a share, as operating costs and expenses declined. During the same period in the prior year, the restaurant operator reported a net loss of $4.5 million, or 5 cents a share. Estee Lauder Cos. EL, -1.37% said its board has authorized buying back up to another 20 million shares, or 9.6% of the total outstanding stock. Hittite Microwave Corp. HITT, +0.00% after Thursday's closing bell reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $12.1 million, or 39 cents a share, up from $7.11 million, or 23 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Ingram Micro Inc. IM, +0.23% reported a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $91.7 million, or 53 cents a share, on revenue of $8.85 billion. During the same period a year ago, the technology products distributor earned $84.4 million, or 51 cents a share, on $7.96 billion in revenue. Medical Properties Trust Inc. MPW, -3.69% said it plans to make a public offering of 12 million shares. Medical Properties Trust is offering a portion, and the rest is being offered in connection with forward sale agreements among Medical Properties Trust and affiliates of the underwriters. Mohawk Industries Inc. MHK, -1.99% said fourth-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $129.5 million, or $1.90 a share, from $99.6 million, or $1.47 a share, during the same period in the prior year. The flooring supplier said quarterly revenue increased to $1.9 billion from $1.8 billion in the prior year. Nabi Biopharmaceuticals NABI said Thomas McLain has resigned as chairman, chief executive and president, effective immediately. The company has appointed Leslie Hudson, a company director since 2005, as interim CEO and president for a six-month term. Oriental Financial Group Inc. OFG, +1.44% said it swung to a fourth-quarter net loss of $18 million, as total interest and non-interest expenses grew. In the same period last year, the financial holding company said net earnings came in at $8.5 million. Pogo Producing Co. PPP, +20.00% swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $16.5 million, or 29 cents a share, from a profit of $114.7 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier. The energy company said revenue fell 18% to $343.1 million from $419.6 million a year ago. Sirenza Microdevices Inc. SMDI said board member Phillip Liao and his wife are selling about 7 million shares of common stock. The radio frequency components supplier noted it will not receive any proceeds from the offering. Universal American Financial Corp. UHCO reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $64 million, or $1.06, compared with $3.9 million, or 6 cents a share, in the same period last year. This year's quarterly results include a $49.9 million gain from the company's sale of its Canadian subsidiary. Wyeth WYE said an Arkansas jury found in favor of the company in a trial related to Wyeth's hormone replacement drugs. In Helene Rush v. Wyeth, which started on Jan. 22, the plaintiff alleged she developed breast cancer from using Premarin and Prempro. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Friday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group Inc. OFG, +1.44% late Thursday said it swung to a fourth-quarter net loss of $18 million, as total interest and non-interest expenses grew. In the same period last year, the financial holding company said net earnings came in at $8.5 million. Oriental Financial posted a net loss available to common shareholders of $19.2 million, or 78 cents a share. Last year, the company reported net earnings available to shareholders of $7.3 million, or 29 cents a share. Total interest income rose 5.3% to $57.2 million from $54.3 million.
title: Oriental Financial swings to quarterly loss

content: Advancers Epix Pharmaceuticals EPIX, +4.55% shares soared 30% after it entered into a drug discovery and development pact with GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.56% As part of deal, Epix will receive an upfront payment of $35 million, which includes $17.5 million from the sale of 3 million shares of its common stock. Epix will also be eligible for up to $1.2 billion for the achievement of certain milestones, and royalties on product sales. Imperial Sugar Co. IPSU shares jumped 15% after it reported that it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss and declared a $3 special dividend. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Imperial earned $15.7 million, or $1.36 a share, compared with a loss of $20.3 million, or $1.92, in the year-earlier period. Continuing operations produced earnings of $1.34 compared with a loss of 26 cents. Sales reached $240.3 million, up 6.1% from $226.6 million. In a statement, Imperial said gross-profit margin widened to 15.5% from 4.7%, primarily because of higher sales prices, offset by higher energy, freight and raw-sugar costs. The special dividend, which comes in addition to the company's regular dividend, is payable Jan. 5 to holders of record Dec. 26. Looking ahead, Imperial said fiscal 2007 prices and margins probably will lag 2006 levels, offset partly by reduced raw-sugar and energy costs. The combination of factors leads the company to believe it can "maintain a profit outlook that is superior to historical averages," Imperial said. Mama.com Inc. MAMA shares surged 81% after the company said it's launched its video search engine in beta format in partnership with the Pixsy Media Search platform. Shares of Nymox Pharmaceuticals NYMX, -2.60% rose 8.3% after the company said it's developing NXC-4720 for the reduction of E-Coli contamination of food products. The company said studies have shown the NXC-4720 product "is capable of reducing the level of E. Coli O157:H7 contamination by over 99%." Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% shares rose 7.1% after the company said it's repositioned its sale investment portfolio, making moves that it expects to increase its net interest income by about $16 million, or 67 cents a share, in 2007. Sabre Holdings Corp. TSG, -3.45% shares climbed 5% after it agreed to be acquired by private-equity firms Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group for about $5 billion, or $32.75 a share. The transaction includes the assumption of about $550 million of debt. The price represents a premium of 30% over the company's average closing share price during the 60 trading days ended Dec. 8, Sabre said. The Southlake, Texas-based travel-booking service said it doesn't expect changes to its current management team. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2007, the company said. See full story. Scotts Miracle-Gro Co. SMG, -2.87% shares rose 5% after it said it plans to recapitalize its balance sheet and return $750 million to its shareholders. It plans to accomplish this through a Dutch auction tender offer for up to $250 million worth of its stock and a special one-time cash dividend for the balance of the program. The provider of consumer lawn and garden products expects to complete the recapitalization, including a new $2.1 billion credit facility, by March 31. Scotts also forecast pro forma net income growth of 11% to 13% for 2007 with sales tabbed to increase between 8% and 10%. It sees free cash flow of more than $165 million for the year. Trailer Bridge Inc. TRBR shares gained 8.5% after it said it's received a contract to the exclusive carrier to Puerto Rico for all new vehicles made by Ford Motor Co. F, -1.99% Financial terms weren't disclosed although the company did say the deal would make Ford its largest customer in revenue terms. Decliners Asiainfo Holdings ASIA, -0.71% shares fell 7% after it agreed to sell its financial services IT business to Fidelity National Information Services FIS, -1.65% AsiaInfo said it will receive an initial $1.5 million, with further payments of up to $1.75 million, depending on the division's performance. AsiaInfo said it is selling the division as part of its ongoing strategy to focus on its core telecommunications business. Celestica Inc. CLS, -2.42% shares slumped 12% after it said it expects between breakeven results and a profit of 6 cents a share on an adjusted basis for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31 on revenue of between $2.20 billion and $2.25 billion. This view is below the company's previous forecast for adjusted earnings of 15 to 23 cents a share in the quarter on revenue of $2.25 billion to $2.45 billion. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 19 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $2.21 billion. The Toronto-based provider of electronics manufacturing services attributed the lower outlook to demand reductions from several customers. It added that the revised adjusted earnings view includes a charge of 8 to 12 cents a share related to an increase in inventory provisions at its Monterrey, Mexico facility. Columbus McKinnon CMCO, -2.71% shares dropped 5.4% after it was initiated with a neutral rating at Sidoti & Co. Continental Airlines CAL, -2.08% shares declined 5.6% after it said it estimates a 6% total rise in capacity, or available seat miles, in the fourth quarter, compared to the same period a year ago. The Houston-based company forecasts a fourth-quarter domestic load factor, or the ratio of seats filled with paying passengers, of 83% to 84%, and an overall load factor of 79% to 80%. In a federal filing, Continental added that its fourth-quarter consolidated cost per available seat mile, an industry measure of operating expenses, would be 11.44 to 11.49 cents; its profit-sharing pool had grown to $106 million; and that its mainline advanced booked seats for the next six weeks would be flat compared to last year. December total revenue is expected to increase between 1% and 3%. Cooper Cos. COO, -3.12% shares fell 6.1% after it was downgraded to underperform from peer perform at Bear Stearns. Delta Petroleum Corp. DPTR shares fell 7.6% after it was downgraded to hold from buy at A.G. Edwards. Endwave Corp. ENWV shares dropped 15% after it said it has lowered its fourth-quarter revenue outlook to $10 million to $12 million. As a result, the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based maker of radio frequency modules now sees 2006 revenue growth of 20% to 25%, down from its prior view of 35%. Indevus Pharmaceuticals IDEV, -1.45% shares slipped 8.8% after it agreed to acquire Valera Pharmaceuticals VLRX, -4.30% in a move to boost its presence in the urology and men's health category and leverage its national sales force. The deal is valued at about $7.75 a share in stock, or about $120 million, plus payments of up to $3.50 a share based on product milestones. Valera shares last traded at $5.41 a share. Upon completion of the deal and subject to the approval of the Indevus board, James Gale, Valera's chairman and chief investment officer of the Corporate Opportunities Funds and Life Sciences Opportunities Fund, affiliates of Sanders Morris Harris, will join the Indevus board. Sanders Morris Harris is currently the largest shareholder of Valera. Separately, Indevus and Valera have entered into a co-promotion agreement under which Indevus' sales force will co-promote Valera's prostate cancer drug Vantas in the U.S. Matrixx Initiatives MTXX, +0.24% shares declined 12% after it said it doesn't expect sales and net income to reach the lower end of its previously disclosed outlook for 2006 due to a slow start to the cold season. The Phoenix-based maker of the Zicam and Nasal Comfort cough and cold products said the overall season-to-date incidence level is about 3% below last year, which is hurting net sales growth. Nucor Corp. NUE, -2.03% shares fell 7.4% after it said it expects fourth-quarter earnings in a range of $1.05 to $1.15 a share, compared with $1.09 a year earlier. The average earnings estimate of 15 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call is $1.44 a share. Nucor, a Charlotte, N.C., steel company, said its forecast for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31 is "historically strong" but is below third-quarter earnings of $1.68 a share. Source Interlink Cos. SORC shares fell 9% after it reported third-quarter net earnings of $4.83 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $6.08 million, or 11 cents a share, in the same period last year, as expenses rose. Spartech Corp. SEH, -3.91% shares declined 16% after it reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $8.62 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $5.16 million, or 16 cents a share, in the same period last year, on the back of stronger sales related to demand after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Tuesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: CORRECT: Emulex quarterly profit rises 15% (9:08 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Emulex Corp. ELX, -4.29% after Thursday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $16.4 million, or 19 cents a share, up 15% from $14.3 million, or 16 cents a share, a year ago. On a pro forma basis, the company posted earnings of 27 cents a share compared with 11 cents a share last year. Revenue at the Costa Mesa, Calif.-based network infrastructure company rose to $104.4 million from $73.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings at 27 cents a share on revenue of $109 million. The company forecast second-quarter earnings of 18 cents to 30 cents a share, or 28 cents to 30 cents a share on a pro forma basis, on revenue of $108 million to $112 million. (Corrects spelling of name in headline.) Frontier Airlines swings to quarterly profit (8:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Frontier Airlines Inc. FRNT, +0.00% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $6.91 million, or 18 cents a share. In the same period a year ago, the company posted a net loss of $2.08 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue at the Denver-based company rose to $258.4 million from $214.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated revenue at $256 million. PXRE reports 3Q net operating loss of $317.4M (8:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- PXRE Group Ltd. SPXT, -2.23% late Thursday reported a third-quarter net operating loss of $317.43 million, or $9.46 per adjusted share, vs. a net operating loss of $73.4 million, or $2.67 per adjusted share, last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated a net operating loss of $8.32 a share. PXRE posted a net loss of $11.17 a share compared with $5.48 a share a year ago. The Bermuda-based reinsurer said Hurricanes Katrina and Rita had an after-tax net impact of $349.9 million in the quarter. Revenue in the quarter was $82.7 million vs. $95.6 million last year, and gross premiums were $236.1 million compared with $125.5 million. The company said it has recently raised $474 million of equity capital, and now has $1.1 billion of pro forma capital. Charles River Labs quarterly profit rises 24% (7:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Charles River Laboratories International Inc. CRL, -3.40% after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $32.6 million, or 44 cents a share, up 24% from $26.3 million, or 51 cents a share, last year. There were 73.4 million shares outstanding in the third quarter, compared with 52.6 million last year. Pro forma earnings were 57 cents vs. 51 cents a year ago. Revenue rose to $273.9 million from $176 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings at 57 cents a share on revenue of $277.4 million. Charles River also raised its stock buyback authorization to $100 million from $50 million. The company expects to repatriate up to $150 million in foreign earnings in the fourth quarter, and as a result, will record a one-time net tax benefit estimated at 20 cents a share. For the fourth quarter, the company expects earnings of 53 cents to 55 cents a share, or 56 cents to 58 cents a share on a pro forma basis, and for sales to increase 19% to 22%. For 2005, Charles River forecast earnings of $1.81 to $1.83 a share, or $2.26 to $2.28 a share on a pro forma basis, on revenue growth of 43% to 46%. Public Storage quarterly earnings, revenue rise (7:00 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Public Storage Inc. PSA, -0.49% after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $128.3 million, or 62 cents a share, vs. $97.5 million, or 38 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Glendale, Calif.-based real estate investment trust posted revenue of $206.9 million vs. $197.2 million. Additionally, the company said its funds from operations during the quarter were 97 cents vs. 76 cents a share last year. Deckers Outdoor earnings, revenue rise (6:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Deckers Outdoor Corp. DECK, -3.83% after the closing bell on Thursday reported third-quarter net earnings of $8.15 million, or 63 cents a share, vs. $5.82 million, or 46 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Goleta, Calif.-based footwear company posted revenue of $69.2 million vs. $55.8 million. The company said it now expects fourth-quarter earnings of 60 cents to 64 cents a share on revenue of $72 million to $75 million. Deckers also forecast full-year 2005 earnings of $2.13 to $2.17 a share on revenue of $246 million to $249 million. For 2006, the company said it sees earnings of $2 to $2.15 a share on revenue of $255 million to $265 million. Avid swings to 3Q loss on Pinnacle acquisition; rev rises (6:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Avid Technology Inc. AVID, -1.32% after Thursday's closing bell reported a third-quarter net loss of $17.8 million, or 46 cents a share. Last year, it earned $19 million, or 54 cents a share. The maker of digital video and audio systems said its results included non-cash charges primarily related to its acquisition of Pinnacle Systems Inc. On a pro forma basis, earnings were $24.2 million, or 60 cents a share. Revenue was $204.4 million, an increase of 39% from $147.4 million a year ago. Varian Semiconductor quarterly profit falls 41% (6:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Varian Semiconductor VSEA after Thursday's closing bell reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $13.6 million, or 36 cents a share, down 41% from $23 million, or 62 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue fell 5.5% to $146.3 million from $154.8 million last year. The company forecast fiscal first-quarter net earnings of 46 cents to 61 cents a share and pro forma earnings of 30 cents to 38 cents a share on revenue of $150 million to $160 million. Eastman Chemical triples profit (6:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Chemical Co. EMN, -2.74% reported late Thursday third-quarter net earnings of $123 million, or $1.50 a share, up from $38 million, or 49 cents, a year ago. The current results include $4 million in restructuring charges vs. $42 million in restructuring charges a year ago. Revenue for the quarter rose to $1.82 billion from $1.65 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call predicted on average that the company would earn $1.24 a share on revenue of $1.75 billion. Prior to the report, shares of the Kingsport, Tenn.-based chemicals, fibers and plastics company closed at $49.40, down $1.20, or 0.6%, for the day. Vulcan Materials profit rises 23% (6:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Vulcan Materials Co. VCM, -1.34% citing sharply higher pricing, reported late Thursday third-quarter net earnings of $122 million, or $1.17 a share, up from $99 million, or 96 cents, a year ago. Total revenue for the quarter rose to $830 million from $723 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call predicted on average that the company would earn $1.26 a share on revenue of $834 million. The company said it sees fourth-quarter earnings from ongoing operations of 64 cents to 84 cents a share. Shares of the Birmingham, Ala.-based roadbed and construction materials company fell $2.41, or 3.6%, to $65.35 ahead of the report. Allegheny swings to profit on higher output, better pricing (6:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allegheny Energy AYE on Thursday posted a third-quarter profit of $35.7 million, or 21 cents a share, vs. a loss of $376.8 million, or $2.40 a share, a year ago. Adjusted earnings from continuing operations came in at $74.8 million, or 45 cents a share, up from $50.6 million, or 37 cents a share, last year. Sales grew to $845.1 million from $723.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a profit, on average, of 38 cents a share with sales of $786.6 million. The company said more power generated at its plants and higher electricity prices contributed to the improved results. Compuware quarterly earnings more than triple; rev dips (5:54 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Compuware Corp. CPWR, +17.45% after the closing bell on Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $24.2 million, or 6 cents a share, vs. $7.41 million, or 2 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Detroit-based software company posted revenue of $292.6 million vs. $295.5 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast second-quarter earnings of 7 cents a share on revenue of $306 million. Roper Industries quarterly profit surges 43% (5:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Roper Industries Inc. ROP, -2.18% after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $39.2 million, or 45 cents a share, up 43% from $27.4 million, or 36 cents a share, last year. Revenue at the Duluth, Ga.-based diversified industrial company rose to $365.2 million from $240.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated revenue at $380.3 million. For 2005, Roper raised its net earnings forecast to $1.64 to $1.70 a share from $1.60 to $1.675 cents a share. Denny's narrows quarterly loss; revenue flat (5:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Denny's Corp. DENN, -1.81% after Thursday's closing bell reported a third-quarter net loss of $3.43 million, or 4 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $11.8 million, or 14 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Spartanburg, S.C.-based restaurant chain posted revenue of $248.7 million vs. $247.1 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter results of breakeven a share on revenue of $248 million. Additionally, Denny's said same-store sales at its company units increased by 1.5% during the quarter, and were up 3.8% at its franchised units in the period. Denny's said it expects same-store sales at its company units to be flat to up 1.5% in the fourth quarter. The company said it sees comparable sales up 2% to 3.5% at its franchised units during the period. BJ's Restaurants quarterly profit surges 92%; rev jumps 45% (5:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- BJ's Restaurants Inc. BJRI, -2.12% after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $2.31 million, or 10 cents a share, up 92% from $1.2 million, or 6 cents a share, last year. Revenue at the Huntington Beach, Calif.-based company rose 45%, to $47.6 million from $32.9 million last year. Same-store sales rose 5.5% in the quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings at 9 cents a share on revenue of $45 million. Bebe Stores quarterly profit rises 19%; rev up 22% (5:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Bebe Stores Inc. BEBE, -1.59% after Thursday's closing bell reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $13.6 million, or 14 cents a share, up 19% from $11.4 million, or 13 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose 22% to $126.2 million from $103.1 million a year ago. Same-store sales rose 17.3% vs. 12.5% in the year-ago period. The clothing retailer forecast second-quarter earnings of 24 cents to 29 cents a share, including a charge of 2 cents a share from expensing stock-based compensation. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect earnings of 31 cents a share on revenue of $179 million. Brisbane, Calif.-based Bebe Stores also sees second-quarter same-store sales in the low- to mid-single digits range. Odyssey Re reports $97M net loss after hurricane hit (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Odyssey Re Holdings ORH, -50.00% reported a third-quarter net loss of $96.9 million, or $1.51 per share, late Thursday after absorbing hits from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Last year, the Stamford, Conn.-based reinsurer made a net profit of $18 million, or 27 cents a share. Operating losses, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses and other items, came in at $153.4 million, or $2.39 per share, versus a loss of $3.4 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier. The company was expected to lose $2.25 per share, according to five analysts in a Thomson First Call survey. "Hurricanes Katrina and Rita have served as painful reminders to the industry of the need to practice disciplined underwriting and risk management," Odyssey Re Chief Executive Andrew Barnard said. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of $1.05 a share on revenue of $6.12 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Bunge's volumes improved to 30.1 million metric tons from 28.9 million in the 2004 third quarter. Chairman and CEO Alberto Weisser noted that Bunge faced "some significant challenges" in the latest quarter, particularly in Brazil. "We believe these challenges are temporary and that the fundamentals in Brazil remain good. On a global level, market conditions are solid," he said. The company also revised higher its 2005 profit outlook and now sees net income of $3.97 to $4.13 a share, assuming stable currencies in South America and Europe. Wall Street's average view stands at $3.67. Shares of Bunge lost 55 cents, or 1.1%, to end Wednesday's trading at $50.43. Magellan Health 3Q profit rises; to redeem $241M in notes (6:47 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Magellan Health Services, Inc. MGLN, -3.97% said third-quarter profit rose 29% to $34.4 million, or 91 cents a share, from the year-ago quarter. Revenue declined slightly to $454.3 million from $458 million. The company also said it will redeem $241 million in senior notes scheduled to mature on Nov. 15. Looking ahead, Magellan said it expects to post 2005 segment profit at the upped end of its $220 million to $240 million range. In 2006, the company expects to post earnings in the range of $1.40 to $1.70 a share. St Paul Travelers 3Q profit falls on hurricane losses (6:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Insurer St Paul Travelers Companies, Inc. STA, -10.00% said third-quarter net profit fell to $162 million, or 23 cents a share, from $340 million, or 50 cents a share on charges related to Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. The company said the losses from the hurricanes were $1 billion after tax, net of reinsurance and including $88 million after tax in reinstatement premiums. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned $75 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to 45 cents a share a year ago. Harvest Natural Resources' quarterly revenue up nearly 33% (6:37 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Harvest Natural Resources Inc. HNR, +0.00% reported third-quarter earnings of $8.1 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $5.3 million, or 14 cents, earned in the same period last year. Quarterly revenue for the energy producer reached $61.2 million from the prior year's $46.1 million, on stronger oil and gas prices. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Harvest Natural's profit to amount to 33 cents a share, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Operating cash flow improved to $26.2 million in the latest quarter from $19.7 million a year earlier. Shares of Harvest Natural lost 21 cents, or 2.2%., to end Wednesday's trading at $9.54. EDO third-quarter net rose 43% on 35% higher revenue (6:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- EDO Corp., EDO the New York defense contractor, reported third-quarter net income rose 43% on 35% higher revenue. Earnings reached $9.8 million, or 48 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 35 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of 49 cents. Revenue advanced to $175.9 million from $129.9 million. First Call's estimate: $178.4 million. The company said the third-quarter revenue number put it on track to meet or exceed its estimate of $630 million to $640 million for the year. First Call's analyst survey indicates an expectation of $652.9 million for the year. The backlog at Sept. 24 was $533.9 million, up 6.5% from a year earlier. EDO shares added a penny to $28 on Wednesday. IHOP 3Q profit rises, lifts earnings outlook (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Restaurant chain IHOP Corp. IHP, -1.15% said third-quarter net profit rose 56% to $12 million, or 62 cents a share, from the year-earlier quarter, thanks to reduced expenses. The company said system-wide same-store sales rose 4.5%. Looking ahead IHOP lifted its earnings outlook for the year to the range of $2.15 to $2.20 from an earlier forecast of between $2.02 and $2.15 a share. AirTran's quarterly revenue growth comes in at 52.5% (6:26 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- AirTran Holdings Inc. AAI, +0.00% reported a third-quarter net loss of $228,000, narrower than the prior year's loss $9.8 million. The latest quarter's loss amounted to nil on a per-share basis, as opposed to the low-cost carrier's year-earlier loss of 11 cents. AirTran posted revenue of $374.6 million, up 52.5% from the prior year's $245.6 million. Analysts, on average, had been looking for AirTran to come in with revenue of $364 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Load factor for the latest quarter improved by more than six percentage points, to 76.3%, as capacity grew by 31.1%. AirTran managed to narrow its quarterly loss even as operating costs including fuel rose by 10.5%, to 9.56 cents. Shares of AirTran added 23 cents, or 1.7%, to end Wednesday's trading at $13.98. Kendle International Q2 net rose on 25% higher revenue (6:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Kendle International Inc., KNDL the Cincinnati clinical-research company, reported third-quarter net income rose on 25% higher revenue. Net reached $3.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from $600,000, or 4 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue climbed to $64.4 million from $51.7 million. The backlog at Sept. 30 rose a third from a year earlier to $300 million. Kendle shares fell $2.05, or 7%, on Wednesday to $27.06. Biomira 9-months loss widens, posts L-BPL25 results (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Biotech company Biomira, Inc. BIOM, +17.14% said its net loss from operations for the nine months to Sept. 30 widened to $14.6 million, or 19 cents a share, compared to $8.6 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The company attributed the shortfall to lower revenue. Biomira also said that median survival for non-small cell lung cancer patients who received liposome vaccine L-BPL25 was 30.6 months compared to 13.3 months for the unvaccinated group. Harleysville Group's quarterly net rises nearly 85% (6:16 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Harleysville Group Inc. HGIC reported third-quarter net income of $16.4 million, or 54 cents a share, up from $8.9 million, or 29 cents, earned in the same period last year. The insurance company's quarterly revenue came in at $239.2 million, up modestly from the prior year's $238.3 million, as net written premiums slipped. Harleysville's overall statutory combined ratio was 102.5% in the latest quarter, compared to 106.6% in the third quarter of 2004. Claims costs for weather-related catastrophes amounted to 5 cents and 13 cents a share in the respective quarters. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $240 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Harleysville Group added 10 cents to end Wednesday's trading at $23.91. Hanover Compressor 3Q loss widens, sales rise (6:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Natural gas compression company Hanover Compressor Co. HC posted a third-quarter net loss that widened to $14.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from $5.3 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding one-time items of $7.9 million, or 15 cents a share, the company would have posted a loss of a penny a share. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 5 cents a share. Revenue for the period rose 17% to $369.8 million due to improved pricing. Shell third-quarter earnings surge 68% to $7.4 billion (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Royal Dutch Shell RDS.A, -1.97% (UK:RDS.A)said third-quarter cost of current supplies earnings rose 68% to $7.37 billion on higher oil and gas prices as well as divestments, some $2 billion above consensus forecasts, though it noted that 2006 production will come in at the lower end of previous forecasts. The oil giant noted that its third quarter was boosted by $1.57 billion in gains on divestments and mark-to-market valuations. Production came in at 3.21 million barrels of oil equivalent a day, down from 3.6 million in the year ago quarter with 160,000 barrels a day decline coming from the impact of hurricanes. 2005 production is seen at around 3.5 million barrels a day, while 2006 production is seen in the lower half of the 3.5 million to 3.8 million barrel a day range, though Shell held to 2009 targets. Alcatel 3Q profit rises, trims FY operating margin outlook (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French telecommunication equipment maker Alcatel SA(FR:013000) ALA, -1.38% on Thursday said third-quarter net profit rose 36% to 266 million euros ($321.6 million), or 19 euro cents a share, but cut its operating margin growth outlook for the year to 9% from an earlier forecast of 10%. The latest quarter's results included 7 euro cents a share in one-time capital gains. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned 12 cents a share, lower than the 14 euro cents a share average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period rose 8.8% to 3.289 billion euros, lower than the 3.637 billion euros anticipated by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, the company said it sees the market remaining very competitive in the fourth quarter. It added it expects the strong seasonal sequential growth to be somehow mitigated by the softness of the Chinese market. Alcatel said it sees fiscal-year revenue growth at the high end of its 5% to 8% range and earnings around 60 euro cents a share. Sony second-quarter profit slides 46.5%, revenue steady (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Sony Corp. SNE, -0.72% said second-quarter net profit fell 46.5% to 53.2 billion yen ($252 million), or 24 cents per U.S. share, with revenue steady at 1.7 trillion yen ($15.07 billion). The quarter included a $650 million gain on the transfer of its pension fund to the Japanese government. Sony said sales of LCD flat panel televisions and video cames rose, but CRT televisions, plasma televisions and digital cameras fell. Sales rose 79.1% on hardware and software sales from the PlayStation Portable, it added, while pictures saw a 17.2% decline on lower theatrical revenue. Boots Group first-half pre-tax trading profit down 9.6% (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. health and beauty retailer Boots Group(UK:BOOT), which earlier this month proposed its merger with Alliance Unichem PLC(UK:AUN), on Thursday said first-half pre-tax trading profit fell 9.6% to 163 million pounds ($290 million). The company attributed the decline to lower U.K. consumer spending and higher infrastructure costs. The group said Boots The Chemist's first-half sales rose 1.1%, with comparable sales down 1.3%. Gross margins fell 0.3 percentage points due to the annualization of price reductions last year, the company said. Boots said it held dividend at 9.1 pence a share. France Telecom 3Q sales rise, cuts FY sales growth outlook (2:03 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- France Telecom FTE, +0.55% (FR:013330)on Thursday said third-quarter sales rose 3.8% to 12.26 billion euros ($14.8 billion), slightly lower than analysts' expectations, and cut its sales growth outlook for the year to a 3% rise versus an earlier forecast of between 3% and 5%. Looking ahead, the French telecom operator reconfirmed its gross operating profit target of 18.5 billion euros for the year. It also said it sees a capex/sales ratio at the top end of its target range of 10% to 12%. Steelmaker Arcelor profit rises 4.5% in third quarter (2:01 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Steel giant Arcelor(FR:005786)said third-quarter net profit rose 4.5% to 657 million euros, with revenue up 4.6% to 7.48 billion euros. Product mix and expansion in Brazil and Argentina offset higher costs and unfavorable market conditions, it said. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Amkor Technology AMKR, -4.84% shares ended Thursday with a 14.4% gain after the company was upgraded at J.P. Morgan to neutral from underweight due to healthy gross margins. Ariba Inc. ARBA stock jumped 11.7% after the company reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $7.27 million, or 11 cents a share, vs. a loss of $22.9 million, or 36 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On a pro forma basis, the company posted net income of $16.4 million, or 24 cents a share. Revenue at the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company fell 8.3%, to $77.1 million from $84.1 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated revenue at $75 million. Shares of Corning Inc. GLW, -3.05% tacked on 6% after the company reported third-quarter net earnings of $203 million, or 13 cents a share. Last year, it lost $2.5 million, or $1.78 a share. Excluding charges of $202 million, or 13 cents a share, Corning would have posted a profit of 26 cents a share. Revenue was $1.19 billion compared with $1 billion last year. Dollar Thrifty Automotive DTG, +0.85% stock gained 8% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $28.4 million, or $1.07 a share, up from $25 million, or 96 cents a share in the year-ago period. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of $1.15 a share for the company. Total revenue was $456.7 million, an 8.5% increase. Express Scripts ESRX, -1.75% stock soared 16.7% after the firm reported a 65% jump in third-quarter net income. See full story. Shares of Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. GT, -1.73% rose 14.7% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $142 million, or 70 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $38 million, or 20 cents a share. Sales rose 7% in the latest three months to $5 billion from $4.7 billion in the same period a year earlier. The Akron, Ohio-based Goodyear cited strong operating results in its tire businesses, improved pricing and product mix, and higher volume in its international operations for the performance. The latest results include charges of $10 million, or 5 cents a share, related to the recent hurricanes in the Gulf Coast. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 38 cents a share in the September period. Tire unit volume rose to 58.4 million units in the quarter, from 57.4 million units in the year-ago period. See full story. Shares of Goody's Family Clothing GDYS tacked on 5% after the company agreed to be acquired by GMM Capital LLC and Prentice Capital Management LP for $9.60 a share cash. I2 Technologies ITWO shares ended the day with an 11.4% gain. The company said it knows of no events or activities to warrant the recent sharp drop in its share price. The stock closed Wednesday down 18% at $11.27, after losing 34% on Tuesday. "We believe we had a strong third-quarter and that the future looks bright for i2," said chief executive Michael McGrath. "Without the impact of our restated revenue from previous years, which we believe is irrelevant to the company's business, we exceeded earnings expectations for the quarter." IHOP Corp. IHP, -1.15% shares added 6.6% after the company said third-quarter net profit rose 56% to $12 million, or 62 cents a share, from the year-earlier quarter, thanks to reduced expenses. The company said system-wide same-store sales rose 4.5%. Looking ahead IHOP lifted its earnings outlook for the year to the range of $2.15 to $2.20 from an earlier forecast of between $2.02 and $2.15 a share. ITT Educational Services ESI, -5.63% stock closed up 11.9% after the company reported third-quarter earnings before items of $30.5 million, or 65 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $24.5 million, or 52 cents a share. Revenue rose 11.9% in the latest three months to $176.8 million from $157.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 61 cents a share in the September period on revenue of $173.7 million. Shares of Openwave Systems OPWV surged 15.2% after the company reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $7.7 million, or 11 cents a share. Last year, it posted earnings of $957,000, or 1 cent a share. On a pro forma basis, the company had a profit of $8.8 million, or 12 cents a share. Revenue increased 24% to $103.3 million from $83.6 million a year ago, said the Redwood City, Calif.-based communications software company. Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% stock gained 16.1% after the company posted earnings of $7.2 million, or 29 cents a share, for the September quarter. This performance was two cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus profit estimate for the period. Par Pharmaceutical PRX shares jumped 16.7% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $25.3 million, or 74 cents a share, on sales of $118.7 million. The latest results include gains from a stock sale and a tax benefit, and a charge related to asset impairment. Excluding items, the Spring Valley, N.Y. drug firm posted earnings of $10 million, or 29 cents a share, ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 26 cents a share. Playtex Products PYX, -5.19% stock rose 14.1% after the company bested Wall Street's expectations for its third-quarter profit. Excluding special items, the company earned $4.5 million, or 7 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $1.7 million, or 3 cents a share, and 4 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company cited a positive product mix, savings from its deleveraging program and successful cost reduction efforts for the strong performance. Russell Corp. RML, +0.00% shares added 5.7% after the company posted third-quarter net income of $15.8 million, or 47 cents a share, down sharply from $26.9 million, or 82 cents a share, due to operational issues that were intensified by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Without those problems, the company estimates that earnings would have been about 60 cents a share. Sales were $424.6 million, contrasting with $422.7 million a year before. The company forecast 2005 adjusted earnings in the range of $1.25 to $1.35 a share; the Thomson First Call average analysts' esimate is for earnings of $1.27 a share. It also forecast full-year sales of $1.45 billion to $1.46 billion. Synergetics USA SURG, +0.00% shares rose 7.4% after the company posted a profit of $1.5 million, or 42 cents a share, on sales of $21.8 million for the fiscal year ended July 31. This performance was above its profit of $1.1 million, or 32 cents a share, on sales of $16.9 million in fiscal 2004. Decliners Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc. AMLN shares ended the session down 10.8% after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $69.5 million, or 65 cents a share, vs. a loss of $34.1 million, or 36 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The San Diego biopharmaceutical company posted revenue of $25.9 million vs. $13.4 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast a third-quarter loss of 57 cents a share on revenue of $31 million. Shares of Axcelis Technologies ACLS, -5.49% plunged 22% after the company was downgraded to hold from buy at Citigroup. Baidu.com Inc. BIDU, -1.40% shares sank 13.2% after the company reported a third-quarter profit that missed Wall Street's consensus estimate and showed a sequential decline of roughly 29%. See full story. Builders Firstsource BLDR, -5.49% shares gave back 8.9% after the company said its third-quarter net income rose 41% to $27.8 billion, or 80 cents a share, from $19.7 million, or 73 cents a share, a year before, due to strong residential construction conditions. The Thomson First Call estimate was for earnings of 63 cents a share. Revenue shot up to $644 million from $575.4 million. The company warned that its fourth-quarter results will be impacted by less robust home-building activity than was seen in the third quarter. Shares of CACI International Inc. CAI, -3.25% sank 13.7% after the company reported a rise in fiscal first-quarter earnings but said certain government contracts will end this fiscal year. See full story. Consol Energy CNX, -6.03% stock lost 9.3% after the company swung to a profit in the third quarter, posting net earnings of $377 million, or $4.04 a share. In the third quarter a year ago, Consol reported a loss of $11.6 million, or 13 cents a share. Analysts, on average, had expected earnings of 78 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. The Pittsburgh, Pa. company said revenue in the third quarter climbed to $1.21 billion from $660 million a year earlier. Curagen Corp. CRGN stock lost 8.1% after the company posted a third-quarter net loss that widened to $22.2 million, or 42 cents a share, from $21.5 million, or 43 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Looking ahead, Curagen lowered its cash burn forecast by $10 million to the range of $65 million to $75 million Deluxe Corp. DLX, -1.84% shares gave back 11.7% after the company said third-quarter profit fell to $37 million, or 73 cents a share, from $58 million, or $1.14, a year ago.. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 declined to $413 million from $472 million in last year's third quarter. For the fiscal year, the St. Paul, Minn.-based marketing services provider forecast earnings at $3.17 to $3.21 a share. Digital River DRIV shares plummeted 26.1% after the Minneapolis-based e-commerce software company gave a disappointing outlook. The company expects fourth-quarter pro forma earnings of 51 cents a share, a penny below Wall Street's consensus view. It also forecast non-GAAP earnings of $1.44 a share for fiscal 2006 on revenue of $250 million. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $259.8 million for the year. Dura Automotive Systems DRRA stock fell 8.2% after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $6.6 million, or 35 cents a share, wider than a year-ago loss of $2.7 million, or 15 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, excluding certain items, the Rochester Hills, Mich.-based Dura posted a loss from continuing operations of $5.2 million, or 28 cents a share, down from a year-ago equivalent profit of $900,000, or 5 cents a share. Revenue slid in the latest three months to $535.9 million from $616.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 23 cents a share in the September period. Looking ahead, the designer of driver control systems sees revenue of between $2.3 billion and $2.4 billion for the full year. Durect Corp. DRRX, +0.00% shares fell 10.9% after the specialty pharmaceutical company proposed making a public offering of common stock under its shelf registration. The offering contemplates Durect selling 7.4 million shares and certain stockholders, including company executives, selling 32,256 shares. Gaylord Entertainment Co. GET, +0.00% stock shed 9.6% after the company said its third-quarter loss widened to $11.6 million, or 29 cents a share, from $3.2 million, or 8 cents, a year ago. The company's loss from continuing operations came to 24 cents a share, which was wider than analysts' average estimate for a loss of 14 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 increased 9% to $208.5 million from $191 million in last year's third quarter. General Motors GM, -1.60% shares gave back 6.8% after the company said it received a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission stemming from a probe of transactions between GM and bankrupt parts supplier Delphi Corp. (DPHQI). The world's largest automobile maker said in a statement that the SEC is also looking into GM's financial reporting of its retiree benefits, how the company accounts for recovery of recall costs from suppliers, and what obligations the Dow component may have to fund retiree benefits in connection with Delphi's bankruptcy proceedings. See full story. Goodrich Corp. GR, +5.88% shares slumped 14.7% after the company reported net income of $60.8 million, or 49 cents a share, up from $49.9 million, or 41 cents a share, but a penny shy of Wall Street's consensus view. Revenue rose to $1.37 billion from $1.16 billion. The company forecast 2005 earnings of $2 to $2.10 a share and also predicted that its 2006 earnings will register double digits growth. It also projected 2005 revenue will be $5.3 billion; the First Call estimate is for $5.29 billion. Halliburton HAL, -1.81% stock lost 5.2% after the company was downgraded by J.P. Morgan to neutral from overweight due to concerns about management credibility and execution. Hanover Compressor Co. HC shares fell 6.6% after the company posted a third-quarter net loss that widened to $14.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from $5.3 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding one-time items of $7.9 million, or 15 cents a share, the company would have posted a loss of a penny a share. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 5 cents a share. Revenue for the period rose 17% to $369.8 million due to improved pricing. Hecla Mining Co. HL, -1.09% ended the session down 7.7%. The company responded to media reports that the Venezuelan tax agency, Seniat, will conduct an accounting review of the company in response to claims of irregularities by the local labor union. "Although we have had no official notice from them, we will certainly cooperate fully with any review by the Seniat to put these allegations to rest," said Phillips Baker, Hecla's chief executive, in a statement. "If the Seniat decides to conduct an investigation, I am sure it will be in an attempt to determine the truth," he said. Venezuela's state news agency had reported that tax chief Jose Vielma Mora said Hecla employees had said the company has bookkeeping problems and conducts illegal gold extraction, according to the AP. Coeur d'Alene, Idaho-based Hecla mines and process silver and gold in the U.S., Venezuela and Mexico. Invacare Corp. IVC, -4.02% stock lost 10.5% after the company reported third-quarter net income that fell to $15.3 million, or 53 cents a share, down from $22.5 million, or 70 cents a share, a year before due partly to restructuring costs. The Thomson First Call estimate was for earnings of 57 cents a share. Sales rose 13% to $395.3 million. ITT Industries ITT, -3.10% shares fell 7.9% after the firm reported third-quarter earnings of $189.3 million, or $2 a share, up from $79.5 million, or $1.16 a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been $1.37 a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.35 a share. Revenue rose to $1.93 billion from last year's $1.66 billion vs. analyst forecasts of $1.91 billion. The diversified industrial and technology company expects 2005 earnings, excluding special items, of $5.35 to $5.40 a share on revenue of $7.7 billion to $7.8 billion, vs. analyst projections for earnings of $5.41 and revenue of $7.8 billion. Jarden Corp. JAH stock closed down 9.3% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $25 million, or 40 cents a share, compared to $22.3 million, or 53 cents a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted income was 74 cents a share. Sales rose 284% to $938 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 68 cents a share. Shares of Kendle International KNDL slumped 11.3% after the company reported third-quarter net income rose on 25% higher revenue. Net income reached $3.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from $600,000, or 4 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Liz Claiborne LIZ shares gave back 9.7% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $114 million, or $1.06 a share, up from $112 million, or $1.03 a share, a year before. The Thomson First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of $1.09 a share. The clothier said results in the recent quarter would have been stronger if high gas prices and rising rates had not hurt shopping traffic. Revenue rose 2.3% to $1.337 billion; the First Call estimate was for $1.38 billion. The company projected flat sales for the fourth quarter, alongside net income of 70 to 74 cents a share; the prior First Call projection was for 80 cents. LSI Logic Corp. LSI, +0.00% stock fell 7.9% after the company reported a narrower third-quarter loss, but offered a weaker sales outlook as the chipmaker restructures its business under new leadership. See full story. Magellan Health Services MGLN, -3.97% shares lost 6.1% after the company said third-quarter profit rose 29% to $34.4 million, or 91 cents a share, from the year-ago quarter. Revenue declined slightly to $454.3 million from $458 million. The company also said it will redeem $241 million in senior notes scheduled to mature on Nov. 15. Looking ahead, Magellan said it expects to post 2005 segment profit at the upped end of its $220 million to $240 million range. In 2006, the company expects to post earnings in the range of $1.40 to $1.70 a share. Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, -3.47% shares ended the session lower by 6.2%. The company said that, despite hurricane-related disruptions to operations, its net income was $770 million, or $2.09 a share, compared with net income of $222 million, or 64 cents a share, in the third quarter of 2004. Minus special items, Marathon would have earned $797 million, or $2.16 a share. Analysts expected Marathon to earn $2.73 a share, on average. Shares of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia MSO, +0.00% skidded 15.2% after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $26 million, or 51 cents a share compared to a loss of $15 million, or 30 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $40.8 million from 38.6 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast a loss of 30 cents a share. Orchid Cellmark ORCH, -0.49% shares plunged 28% after the company posted a loss of $3.8 million, or 15 cents a share, in the fiscal third quarter, wider than a year-ago loss of $400,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said its revenue, which was flat at $16.4 million for the quarter, was hurt by weak business from U.S. forensic casework production due to the implementation of new laboratory processes, lower than expected DNA analyst staffing, and continued delays in forensic DNA testing contracts with the U.S. National Institute of Justice. Phelps Dodge Corp. PD, -4.47% shares fell 5.5% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $366.1 million, or $3.61 a share, up from $292.9 million, or $2.95 a share, a year before, citing a strong rise in copper prices. The Thomson First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of $4.01 a share. Revenue rose to $1.86 billion from $1.42 billion; the First Call estimate was for $2.21 billion. Presstek Inc. PRST, +0.00% shares tumbled 24.9% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $823,000, or 2 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $2.7 million, or 8 cents a share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate of the company's results. The company said its performance was hurt by a decision to realign its direct imaging distribution agreements worldwide. Shares of Respironics RESP shed 5.4% after the company reported first-quarter net income of $18.6 million, or 25 cents a share, up from $15.2 million, or 21 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 20% to $240.2 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 28 cents a share. Skechers USA SKX, -2.08% shares slumped 22% after the company posted an in-line profit for the third quarter but disappointed Wall Street with its outlook for the fourth quarter. Stewart Information Services STC, -1.87% stock closed down 7.1% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $31.8 million, or $1.74 a share, up from $21.1 million, or $1.16 a share, a year before, noting that favorable long-term rates positively impacted residential and commercial real estate closings. The Thomson First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of $1.87 a share. Revenue rose 21% to $639.4 million or $529.7 million. Stoneridge SRI, +0.87% shares fell 12.7% after the company said it swung to a third-quarter loss of $3.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from a year-ago profit of $3.9 million, or 17 cents. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for the company to post breakeven results on a per-share basis. Sales for the three months ended Oct. 1 fell to $158.7 million from $164.3 million in last year's third quarter. Superior Industries International SUP, -1.88% shares lost 5.6% after the company posted a third-quarter loss of $501,000, or 2 cents a share, against year-earlier net income of $5.5 million, or 20 cents a share, noting problems in the company's aluminum suspension components division. Thomson First Call had estimated a loss of 1 cent a share. Revenue fell 5.9% to $187.6 million in the latest three months. Timberland Co. TBL, +0.00% shares slumped 12.5% after the company said its third-quarter net income rose to $69.2 million, or $1.02 a share, from $68.6 million, or 96 cents a share, a year earlier. The Stratham, N.H., company said earnings excluding restructuring charges rose to $1.05 in the quarter ended Sept. 30. Revenue rose to 2.4% to $505.9 million from $493.9 million. The average earnings estimate of 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 99 cents a share. Shares of Trident Microsystems TRID fell 6.1% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $4.42 million, or 14 cents a share, vs. $1.38 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Pro forma income was 25 cents a share compared with 4 cents a share last year. Revenue at the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based digital television technology company doubled, rising to $33.2 million from $16.6 million last a year ago. Van der Moolen VDM shares closed down 9.3% after the company said it earned 2.3 million euros, or 6 euros a share in the third quarter 2005 compared with 600,000 euros, or 2 euros a share a year ago. The firm's revenues dipped 2% to $26.7 million euros from $26.8 million euros and its operating profit climbed 27% to 7.9 million euros from 6.1 million euros. See full story. Wendy's International WEN, -3.65% shares gave back 5% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $72.1 million, or 61 cents a share, up 4.3% from $69.1 million, or 60 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Dublin, Ohio-based restaurant chain rose to $960.6 million from $914 million. Same-store sales fell 5% at U.S. company stores and 5.5% at U.S. franchised restaurants. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings at 57 cents a share on revenue of $952 million. The company lowered its 2005 pro forma earnings forecast to a range of $2.12 to $2.15 a share from $2.20 to $2.26 a share. Wendy's also said it now expects to open 425 to 450 new stores in 2005. XM Satellite Radio Holdings XMSR shares tumbled 10.1% after the company posted a third-quarter net loss of $131.9 million, or 60 cents a share, deeper than the year-ago loss of $118 million, or 59 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $153 million from $65 million. The company reaffirmed its six million subscriber outlook. More from MarketWatch More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% rose 15.5% to $11.99 on Thursday after the San Juan, Puerto Rico-based financial services company posted earnings of $7.2 million, or 29 cents a share, for the September quarter. This performance was two cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus profit estimate for the period.
title: Oriental Financial rallies as Sept. quarter's earns top view

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group Inc. OFG, +1.44% said Wednesday that it has agreed to distribute American Express Co. AXP, -2.44% consumer and commercial card products in Puerto Rico. In addition to issuing American Express cards, under the agreements, San Juan, P.R.-based Oriental Financial will also accept monthly payments in its branches on American Express cards issued directly by American Express or through Oriental.
title: Oriental Fin'l, AmEx in Puerto Rico card distribution deal

content: Kindred Healthcare profit rises, to buy back stock (8:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, -1.64% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $66.1 million, or $1.43 a share, vs. $21.8 million, or 52 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Louisville, Ky.-based company rose to $1.04 billion from $885.8 million last year. The company also said it plans to buy back up to $100 million in stock. FMC Corp quarterly profit rises (8:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FMC Corp. FMC, -2.06% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $31.2 million, or 80 cents a share, vs. $30.7 million, or 82 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based chemical company rose to $565.6 million from $534.3 million last year. FMC expects third quarter pro forma earnings of 80 cents to 90 cents a share. For 2005, the company forecast pro forma per-share profit in the range of $4.30 to $4.40. Technical Olympic quarterly profit soars 90% (7:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Technical Olympic USA Inc. TOA, +14.04% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $45.7 million, or 79 cents a share, a gain of 90% from $24.1 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Homebuilding revenue at the Hollywood, Fla.-based company rose to $615.8 million from $498.3 million last year. The company raised its 2005 earnings forecast to $185 million, or $3.01 a share, from $170 million, or $2.88 a share. It expects 2005 revenue of $2.4 billion. The homebuilder also said it expects 2006 net income of $285 million, or $4.42 a share, on revenue of $2.8 billion. Aon 2Q profit tops estimates; sees 3Q charge (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aon Corp. AOC, -3.71% said late Tuesday that second-quarter operating profit rose to $193 million, or 58 cents per share, from $180 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. The second-largest insurance broker was expected to report earnings of 48 cents per share in the period, according to a Thomson First Call survey of 15 analysts. Aon also said that it will take a third-quarter, pretax charge of $200 million to $300 million to pay for a restructuring initiative. That reorganization plan will likely save the company $100 million to $150 million annually, Aon continued. Organic revenue growth in the company's main insurance brokerage division declined 2%, the company added. Viisage quarterly loss widens; names new CFO (6:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Viisage Technology Inc. VISG Tuesday evening reported a second-quarter loss of $505,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with a loss of $317,000, or 1 cent a share, a year ago. The number of shares used to compute results for the period were 48 million vs. 35.8 million shares a year ago. Revenue rose to $20.1 million from $16.3 million last year. The identity technology company said it still expects 2005 revenue of $73 million to $80 million, and sees third-quarter revenue of $16 million to $20 million. Billerica, Mass.-based Viisage also named Bradley Miller as chief financial officer, effective Sept. 6. Miller succeeds Bill Aulet, who plans to return to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a senior lecturer. Axis quarterly profit rises above analyst forecasts (6:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Axis Capital AXS, -0.92% said late Tuesday that second-quarter operating profit climbed to $170.9 million, or $1.12 per share, from $144.7 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. The Bermuda-based insurer and reinsurer was expected to earn $1.06 per share in the period, according to a poll of eight analysts by Thomson First Call. Axis also said an internal review -- started in the wake of New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's lawsuit against broker Marsh & McLennan -- found no wrongdoing. The company's combined ratio -- a measure of claims and expenses as a percentage of premiums -- came in at 74.5% in the quarter versus 75.2% a year ago, Axis added. Netease.com quarterly profit more than doubles (5:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Netease.com NTES, -1.62% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter earnings of $29.3 million, or 83 cents per American Depositary Share, compared with $11.9 million last year. Revenue jumped to $50.4 million from $26.5 million a year ago, said the Chinese Internet company. It also said director Ronald Lee has resigned, effective immediately, and that it has named Lun Feng and Mingyong Chen to the board. National Financial 2Q profit rises above forecasts (5:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- National Financial Partners NFP, -30.23% said late Tuesday that second-quarter net income climbed to $12.4 million, or 32 cents per share, from $10.2 million, or 28 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Cash earnings, which exclude amortization of intangibles, depreciation and impairment of goodwill and intangible assets, came in at $22.1 million, or 58 cents per share, the distributor of life insurance and other financial products to wealthy individuals and companies added. National Financial was expected to make 57 cents per share in the period, according to a survey of 11 analysts by Thomson First Call. National Financial also said that an internal review of its insurance operations found no bid-rigging, inflated quotes or collusion with insurers. CORRECT: Cephalon loss widens, outlook reduced (5:09 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Cephalon Inc. CEPH on Tuesday reported a second-quarter net loss of $249 million, or $4.29 a share, compared with a loss of $8.38 million, or 15 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue was $286 million vs. last year's $239.5 million. Excluding acquisition costs and other one-time items, the company's income would have been 69 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of 59 cents a share. The company said it now expects earnings to be cut by 10 cents to $2.70 to $2.85 a share due to its acquisition of Salmedix. (Corrects revenue figures for both 2005 and 2004 quarters.) Brocade Comm sees 3Q net loss, lower revenue (4:59 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Brocade Communications BRCDE after Tuesday's closing bell warned that its fiscal third-quarter results would come in below its previous expectations. The company, which makes switches and other networking products used to operate data storage systems, sees a loss of 3 cents to 4 cents a share on revenue of $121 million to $122 million. It previously forecast pro forma earnings of 5 cents to 6 cents a share on revenue of $140 million to $145 million. It also sees gross margin of 51% to 52%, compared with its prior view of 55% to 57%. Brocade cited, in part, a transition in its product line to a new technology for the revenue shortfall. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call currently expect earnings of 6 cents a share on revenue of $143 million. Borland Software reports $17.5 million loss (4:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Borland Software Corp. BORL on Tuesday fell to a second-quarter loss of $17.5 million, or 23 cents a share, compared to a profit of $2.8 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue slipped to $66.6 million from $76.5 million. Excluding one-time items, Borland earned $74,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis. On that basis, analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast Borland to lose 2 cents a share on $67 million in revenue. OraSure Tech quarterly profit surges (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- OraSure Technologies Inc. OSUR, -1.42% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, vs. $142,000, or breakeven a share, in the year-ago periord. Revenue at the Bethlehem, Pa.-based medical products manufacturer rose to $17.4 million from $13.2 million. The company raised its 2005 earnings forecast to 14 cents to 16 cents a share from 10 cents to 12 cents a share. Analog Devices warns of revenue shortfall (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Analog Devices ADI, -2.61% warned Tuesday that revenue for its third fiscal quarter will come in below previous estimates because of a decline in chipset sales to wireless handset customers. The company now expects revenue between $580 million and $585 million, down 3%-4% from the previous quarter. Previous forecasts called for a 0-3% rise in revenue for the period. Earnings for the quarter are expected to be 31 cents a share. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 33 cents a share on revenue of $617.2 million, according to Thomson First Call. Nortel Networks to now report 2Q results on Monday (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Nortel Networks Corp. NT (CA:NT)said Tuesday it has pushed back the release of its second-quarter results to Aug. 8 from Aug. 3. The Canadian networking company said it changed its reporting date to more closely align with the filing of its second-quarter results with the Securities and Exchange Commission. RealNetworks reports quarterly profit (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- RealNetworks Inc. RNWK, -0.98% late Tuesday swung to a second-quarter net profit of $4.7 million, or 3 cents a share. That compared with a loss of $4.7 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue rose 26% to $82.7 million. The Internet music and video provider said it had over 2 million paid subscribers for its premium services, up from over 1.4 million at the same time last year. Looking ahead, it expects third-quarter revenue in range of $80 million to $82 million. Pacer International adjusted income meets estimates (4:31 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Pacer International Inc. PACR reported second-quarter adjusted income of $11.3 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $9.5 million, or 25 cents a share in the same period in 2004. That matched the average analyst estimate from a survey by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $454.6 million from $421.6 million at the Concord, Calif.-based freight logistics company. Shares fell 20 cents Tuesday to $25.75. Tech Data cuts 2Q EPS view on restructuring charges (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tech Data Corp. TECD, -5.92% said after Tuesday's closing bell that it expects second-quarter earnings of $12.5 million to $16.5 million, or 21 cents to 28 cents a share, compared with its previous forecast of $24 million to $27 million, or 40 cents to 45 cents a share. The forecasts exclude charges related to restructuring efforts in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, as well as other costs. Tech Data cited lower-than-expected gross margin, primarily in the EMEA region, for the expected earnings decline. The company forecast sales of $4.8 billion to $4.82 billion, the high end of its previous forecast. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect Tech Data to report second-quarter earnings of 43 cents a share on revenue of $4.77 billion. UnumProvident 2Q profit tops estimates by a penny (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- UnumProvident Corp. UNM, -1.95% said late Tuesday that second-quarter operating profit came in at $128.7 million, or 42 cents per share, slightly lower than the $130.9 million, or 43 cents a share, that the disability insurer earned in the same period a year earlier. The result topped the average estimate of 14 analysts in a Thomson First Call survey by a penny. Total revenue climbed 6% to $2.7 billion in the second quarter, UnumProvident added. Operating income differs from net income because it excludes net realized investment gains and losses and other one-time items. Insurers often report the figure because they say it's a more accurate indication of the performance of their main underwriting businesses. Insurance analysts also frequently focus on operating income. BMC Software falls into loss on charges (4:20 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- BMC Software Inc. BMC, -2.86% late Tuesday said it fell into a fiscal first-quarter loss as it booked tax and restructuring charges. The company lost $41.1 million, or 19 cents a share, reversing a year-earlier profit of $10.7 million, or 5 cents a share. Excluding the charges, the company would have earned $43.9 million, or 20 cents a share, for the period to easily outpace analysts' expectations. Quarterly revenue rose 6.8% to $348.3 million from $326 million. Wall Street analysts, on average, expected the company to earn 13 cents a share on revenue of $334.9 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Looking ahead, the company also boosted its financial outlook. United Therapeutics surges to near 5-yr. high (2:56 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of United Therapeutics UTHR, -4.40% hiked up 24% to a near 5-year high after the drugmaker reported better-than-expected second-quarter results. Earnings rose to $12.2 million, or 49 cents a share from $4.1 million, or 18 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and topped the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 33 cents a share. Revenue increased 64% to $30.1 million, topping analyst forecasts of $25.4 million. Deutsche Bank analyst Jennifer Chao followed by raising her stock price target to $68 from $64 on the "blowout" results, and reiterated her buy rating. The stock was last up $12.80 at $66.85, the highest price seen since November 2000. Digital Recorders sees 2Q loss; sales of $12.7M (2:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Digital Recorders Inc. TBUS said Tuesday that it expects to report second-quarter sales of $12.7 million, compared with $11.7 million a year ago. The company, which makes mass transit-related surveillance equipment, also expects to post a net loss before taking $550,000 in non-cash charges related to the financing of its preferred stock. Digital Recorders said its quarterly results reflect, in part, continued market softness due to a delay in the reauthorization of the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century.
