It said it doesn't expect the reauthorization to affect revenue in 2005, but forecast stronger market conditions once the legislation is signed by President Bush. Lehman analyst cuts MMC price target, estimates (2:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lehman Brothers analyst Jay Gelb cut his price target and earnings estimates on Marsh & McLennan MMC, -1.96% on Tuesday because he thinks the insurance broker's profit and revenue will continue to be pressured by softening insurance prices and the loss of highly profitable contingent commissions. Gelb took his price target on Marsh down to $27 from $28 and lowered his 2005 earnings per share estimate to $1.71 from $1.76 and his 2006 profit forecast to $2.10 per share from $2.20. Expense cuts and jettisoning lower-margin business will only partially offset these negative trends, Gelb added in a note to clients. Blockbuster CEO: Industry decline had neg impact on Q2 (12:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Blockbuster Inc.'s BBI, -3.85% Chairman and Chief Executive John Antioco said on Tuesday that overall industry decline and continued poor theatrical performance have had a negative impact on its second quarter and has created uncertainty for the rest of the year. Antioco made the comments to holders of Blockbuster's bank debt, according to a company statement. Antioco said the company is "taking aggressive actions" to address the continued weakness in the rental industry. The Dallas-based movie and game rental company is scheduled to release its second-quarter financial results on Aug. 9. Oriental Financial slides as earns fall below forecasts (12:52 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% fell 9.6% after the company reported late Monday fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that fell below expectations. The Puerto Rico-based financial services company said it earned $6.4 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $16.9 million, or 67 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 34 cents a share. The company the flattening yield curve narrowed interest spreads, while continued interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve led to higher interest costs. Interest income rose 15% to $48.9 million, while interest expenses grew 49% to $29.6 million. Non-interest income fell 49% to $6.4 million. The stock was last down $1.51 at $14.29. Evolving Systems slumps on lowered revenue outlook (12:30 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Evolving Systems EVOL, +0.74% dropped 11% after the wireless communications software company lowered its 2005 revenue forecast to $40 million to $46 million from $44 million to $50 million. For the second-quarter, company reported a loss of $689,000, or 4 cents a share, wider than the year-earlier loss of $168 million, or a penny a share. Revenue nearly doubled to $9.9 million from $5.3 million in the same period a year ago. The stock was last trading down 31 cents at $2.55. Aristotle rallies as earns, rev. increase (12:13 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Aristotle Corp. ARTL, +0.00% surged 13% after the maker of educational, health and agricultural products reported second-quarter earnings that rose to $2.6 million, or 15 cents a share from $1.6 million, or 9 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $50.2 million from last year's $44.6 million, due primarily to strength in its educational business. Cash generation improved to $8.1 million from last year's $5.9 million. The stock was last up 83 cents at $7.12. KCS Energy 2Q profit rises 44%; ups '05 capex budget (10:55 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- KCS Energy KCS on Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $20.9 million, or 42 cents a share, up 44% from $14.5 million, or 29 cents a share, last year. Total revenue was $78.7 milllion, a 55% increase from $50.6 million a year ago. The Houston-based oil and gas company also said its board approved an 18% increase in its 2005 capital expenditure budget to $225 million, excluding acquisitions, from $190 million. MMC CEO: recovery from regulatory tangles has been slow (10:45 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Marsh & McLennan MMC, -1.96% Chief Executive Michael Cherkasky said on Tuesday that the insurance broker's recovery from regulatory problems has been slow and that the company hasn't generated as much new business as hoped. A new pricing model that was expected to see progress in the second quarter won't be rolled out until the fourth quarter and the benefits of this won't be realized until 2006, Cherkasky added during a conference call with analysts. Still, Cherkasky said the rate at which Marsh is retaining clients has improved and is near to levels seen in the second quarter of 2004. The chief executive also said he's confident about the company's new pricing model and expects the plan will replace up to one quarter of the revenue Marsh lost when it gave up controversial payments from insurers called contingent commissions last year. Sempra Energy second quarter earnings flat, revenue up (9:52 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - Sempra Energy SRE, -0.98% parent of San Diego Gas & Electric and Southern California Gas Co., on Tuesday reported second-quarter earnings of $121 million, or 48 cents a share, versus $121 million, or 52 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $2.3 billion in the second quarter, up from $2 billion. A poll of analysts by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 69 cents a share. Sempra increased its 2005 earnings outlook to $3.20 to $3.40 a share from $3.10 to $3.30. The First Call estimate for the full year is $3.10 to $3.35 a share. Pioneer Natural earnings more than double (9:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pioneer Natural Resources Co. PXD, -2.84% Tuesday reported second-quarter net income of $185.6 million, or $1.28 a share, up 166% from $69.7 million, or 58 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Income from continuing operations for the quarter was $103.5 million, or 74 cents a share, compared to $64.2 million, or 54 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $592.6 million from $426.1 million. The average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First call was for earnings of 66 cents a share. Shares of the oil and natural gas producer closed Monday at $44, up 67 cents. Equity Office Properties swings to second quarter loss (9:21 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Equity Office Properties Trust EOP on Tuesday posted a second-quarter loss of $205.4 million, or 51 cents a share, including $367 million in charges. In the same period a year ago, the company reported earnings of $100.6 million, or 25 cents a share. The Chicago office building owner and management company sold 60 assets for $1.3 billion in the second quarter. Revenue for the period rose to $757.1 million from 748.9 million in the year-earlier period. Marsh & McLennan earns decline, but top expectations (9:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Marsh & McLennan Companies MMC, -1.96% reported second-quarter earnings of $166 million, or 31 cents a share, down from $389 million, or 73 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 43 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 41 cents a share. Revenue rose 2.2% to $3.1 billion from last year's $3.03 billion, vs. analyst forecasts of $3.08 billion, as a 3% increase in service revenue to $3.05 billion offset a 29% drop in investment income to $51 million. Putnam revenue fell 13% to $377 million. The risk and insurance and investment management services company's stock closed Monday down a penny at $28.96. Rowan reverses year-ago loss (9:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Rowan Cos. RDC, -2.25% an offshore driller, reported a second-quarter profit compared with a year-ago loss Tuesday, as average daily rates for its rigs reached a record in the Gulf of Mexico. Rowan said it earned $42.3 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with a loss of $2.1 million, or 2 cents a share, in the 2004 quarter. From continuing operations alone, the quarterly profit would have been $43.2 million, or 39 cents a share. Analysts had expected earnings of 31 cents a share, on average. ServiceMaster revenue rises 8% (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The ServiceMaster Co. SVM, -1.86% Tuesday reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $80.2 million, or 27 cents a share, up from $70.7 million, or 24 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 8% to $1.2 billion. The average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First call was for earnings of 25 cents a share. Looking ahead, the Downers Grove, Ill. provider of services to residential and commercial customers expects revenue to grow in the mid-to- high single digit range and earnings per share to grow faster than revenue. Earnings per share growth in the second half will be comparable to the first half, the company said. Shares of ServiceMaster closed Monday at $13.56, down 18 cents. Vishay Intertechnology results hurt by charges (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vishay Intertechnology VSH, -2.96% on Tuesday reported a sharp decline in second-quarter earnings after recordings several charges, which cut earnings by 7 cents a share. The company said it earned $9.72 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with earnings of $41.12 million, or 22 cents a share, reported a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of 9 cents a share, on average. Molson Coors profit falls, will restate1Q results (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Molson Coors Brewing Co. TAP, -2.97% on Tuesday said second quarter net income fell to $38.5 million, or 45 cents a share, down from $72 million, or $1.90 a share, for the same period last year. The company was expected to earn $1.61 according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Sales rose to $2.19 billion from $1.55 billion during the same period last year. The Denver, Colo.-based brewer also said it will restate its first quarter earnings to reflect a tax adjustment. Molson shares rose $1.12 on Monday to close at $63.82. Expeditors International profit meets estimates (8:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Freight forwarder Expeditors International of Washington Inc. EXPD, -1.66% reported second-quarter earnings of $44.6 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with $37.6 million, or 34 cents a share in the year-earlier period. That matched the 40-cents-a-share average estimate from analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $928 million from $798.7 million. The stock fell 27 cents to $54.78 on Monday. Accredited Home earnings $1.81 vs $1.60 (8:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Accredited Home Lenders Holding Co. LEND said Thursday that second-quarter earnings were $39.6 million, or $1.81 a share, an increase of 15.4% over $34.3 million, or $1.60 per share, in the year-ago period. Total net revenues for the quarter increased by 21.8% to $143.7 million from $118.0 million. The mortgage banking company sees third-quarter earnings of $1.85 a share. On Monday, Accredited shares rose 59 cents to $48.10. Phoenix Tech restates quarterly earnings lower (8:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Phoenix Technologies PTEC, -0.30% Tuesday restated its third-quarter net income to $700,000 or 3 cents a share, down from its original report of $1 million, or 4 cents a share. The company said the lowered result was linked to a reversal of $450,000 in revenue recorded in the original report. The change will cut quarterly revenue to $23.7 million from $24.2 million. Phoenix Technologies said it changed the figures after an internal probe of a software license transaction with execution problems in its Tokyo office. On Monday the company's stock rose 17 cents to $6.97. Hawk quarterly net rises, raises '05 revenue outlook (8:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Molded components and materials maker Hawk Corp. HWK, -2.50% said second-quarter net income rose to $1.71 million, or 17 cents a share, from $1.47 million, or 16 cents. Sales increased by 11.8% to $70.9 million, benefiting from improved economic conditions and new product introductions in a majority of the company's end markets. The company raised the range of expected revenue for the year to between $270 million and $273 million, which represents an 11.9% to 13.2% increase over 2004 revenue. Hawk affirmed 2005 net income guidance of 35 cents to 40 cents a share. Cooper Tire reports $6.8M loss for recent quarter (8:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. CTB, -3.07% on Tuesday reported a second-quarter loss of $6.88 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to $33 million in net income, or 46 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenues fell less than 1% to $509 million, down from $511 million during the same period last year. The Findlay, Ohio-based tire maker was expected to earn 3 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares of Cooper rose 65 cents on Monday to closed at $20.77. NorthWestern quarterly loss narrows (8:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- NorthWestern Corp. NWEC a supplier of electricity and natural gas in the upper Midwest and Northwest, said second-quarter net loss narrowed to $3.9 million, or 11 cents per share, from a loss of $4.8 million, including a $10.3 million after-tax loss from the settlement reached in the bankruptcy proceedings of NorthWestern subsidiary Netexit Inc. "(Netexit bankruptcy and the PPL Montana litigation) settlements should result in the company receiving significant cash payments by year-end 2005," it said. Revenue rose 14.5% to $249.4 million. Tenet Healthcare narrows quarterly loss (8:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, -4.37% said it narrowed its second-quarter net loss to $21 million, or 4 cents a share, from $426 million, or 91 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts for Thomson First Call had anticipated a loss of 3 cents a share. Revenue for the period declined to $2.42 billion from $2.5 billion a year ago. Same-hospital net outpatient revenue per visit rose to $538 from $517. The company reiterated that the filing of its 10-Q form is likely to be delayed by developments arising out of the previously disclosed investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Argosy Gaming net income, revenue rise (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Argosy Gaming Co. AGY, -2.78% Tuesday reported second-quarter net income of $21.7 million, or 73 cents a share, up from $18.6 million, or 63 cents a share, a year ago. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 71 cents a share. Revenue at the Alton, Ill. operator of casinos and related businesses rose 6.4% to $270.9 million during the period. Shares of Argosy Gaming closed Monday at $46.80, up a penny. Perot Systems net income, sales rise (8:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Information technology services provider Perot Systems Corp. PER, -2.63% said second-quarter net income rose 49% to $32.6 million, or 27 cents a share. Revenue for the period climbed 13% to $488.2 million. The results included a benefit of 6 cents per share associated with a $7.6 million payment to Perot and a $2.7 million reduction in accrued liabilities. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned 21 cents a share, in line with the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Perot expects third-quarter earnings in the range of 21 to 22 cents a share on revenue between $508 million and $522 million. Remington Oil and Gas earns, rev. rise (8:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Remington Oil and Gas REM, -0.87% reported second-quarter earnings of $24.9 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $15 million, or 53 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $77.8 million from last year's $58.4 million, amid a 20% increase in average equivalent oil and gas prices. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 86 cents a share and revenue of $74.2 million, on average. The oil and gas exploration company's stock closed Monday up 74 cents at $40.15. Blount Int'l second-quarter earnings, revenue rise (8:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Blount International BLT, +1.93% the chainsaw and lawnmower maker, said second-quarter profit rose to $17.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $8.4 million, or 25 cents a share, helped by lower interest expenses and higher operating income. Sales rose 14.5% to $193.8 million. MBIA reports 14% decline in net income to $188 mil. (8:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Bond insurer MBIA Inc. MBI, -3.78% on Tuesday said second-quarter net income fell 14% to $188 million, or $1.37 a share, down from $218 million, or $1.49 a share during the same period last year. The Armonk, N.Y.-based company was expected to earn $1.34 a share, according to an analyst survey by Thomson First Call. Shares closed down 58 cents to $60.16 on Monday. China Fin Online down 5.8% on second-quarter results (8:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shares of China Finance Online Co. JRJC, -7.66% dropped 5.8% to $5.70 in premarket trading Tuesday. The decline came after the financial information data provider reported after Monday's closing bell second-quarter net income of $1.01 million, up 7% from $942,000 in the same period a year earlier. Earnings were 5 cents per American Depository Receipt or 1 cent a share. Revenue rose 38% to $1.84 million for the three months ended June 30, primarily due to the growth in advertising-related business. But revenue decreased from the first quarter due to the negative impact of the prolonged weak Chinese stock market. IAC/Interactive 2Q net income surges, tops forecast (7:59 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- IAC/Interactive Corp. IACI, +0.00% said that second-quarter net income surged to $618.1 million, or 89 cents a share, from $69.9 million, or 9 cents a share, a year ago. On an adjusted basis, net income rose 23% to $214.9 million, or 30 cents a share, which was ahead of First Call estimates of 25 cents a share. Second-quarter net revenues rose to $1.96 billion, from $1.46 billion a year ago, after 52% growth in services revenue, 47% growth in retailing revenue and 66% growth in media and advertising revenues. The sector revenue figures exclude the company's online travel services company Expedia, the spinoff of which is expected to be complete next week, the company said. Expedia quarterly net rises ahead of spinoff (7:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Online travel agent Expedia, Inc. EXPED said second-quarter net income rose to $73.4 million from $48.5 million a year ago as revenue increased 14% to $555 million. Bookings for the period climbed 26% to $4.14 billion. The spinoff of Expedia is expected to start next week, with IAC and Expedia beginning to trade as independent public companies on Aug. 9. Checkpoint Systems reverses loss (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Checkpoint Systems Inc. CKP, +1.03% reported second-quarter earnings Tuesday of $9.5 million, or 25 cents a share, reversing a $6.4 million, 17 cents a share loss for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $210.4 million from $189.3 million. Excluding restructuring charges, income was 36 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 25 cents a share. Stock in the Thorofare, N.J.-based maker of security devices for retailers rose 23 cents Monday to $17.51. EnPro Indus. earns, rev. rise (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- EnPro Industries NPO, -2.43% reported second-quarter earnings of $21.1 million, or 99 cents a share, up from $8.4 million, or 40 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 62 cents a share. Revenue rose to $219.4 million from last year's $216.3 million. The sealing products company's stock closed Monday up 19 cents at $30.59. Dril-Quip earnings more than double (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Dril-Quip Inc. DRQ, -3.57% Tuesday reported second-quarter net income of $6.7 million, or 37 cents a share, more than double the $2.8 million, or 16 cents a share, it earned a year before. The company attributed the improvement to rising worldwide demand for its offshore drilling and production equipment. Revenue shot up 52% to $80.6 million. On Monday the company's stock rose 6.6% to $35.40. Emerson earns rise above forecasts, rev. matches ests. (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Emerson EMR, -2.96% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $358 million, or 86 cents a share, up from $341 million, or 81 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been $1 a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 95 cents a share. Revenue rose 11% to $4.47 billion from last year's $4.04 billion, matching analyst forecasts. For fiscal 2005, the electrical products maker raised its adjusted earnings forecast to $3.45 to $3.50 a share, vs. analyst projections of $3.45 a share. The stock closed Monday unchanged at $65.80. Transocean earnings soar on one-time gain, top forecast (7:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Offshore drilling contractor Transocean, Inc. RIG, -2.73% said second-quarter net income soared to $301.8 million, or 90 cents a share, from $48 million, or 15 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period rose to $727.4 million from $633.2 million a year ago. Excluding the benefit from the sale of the jackup Transocean Jupiter and Land Rig, the company would have earned $127.7 million, or 38 cents a share, topping the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 33 cents a share. Steven Madden earns, rev. rise, top expectations (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Steven Madden SHOO, -1.82% reported second-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 39 cents a share, up from $4.1 million, or 28 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 38 cents a share. Revenue rose 17% to $101 million from last year's $86.2 million, topping analyst forecasts of $100.3 million, amid a 24% increase in retail revenue. Same-store sales grew 14%. The shoe seller expects 2005 earnings of 90 to 93 cents a share, surrounding analyst projections of 92 cents, and revenue growth in the mid single-digit percentage range. The stock closed Monday up 12 cents at $22.47. Amvescap pretax slips, with U.S. mutual funds weakness (7:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fund manager operator Amvescap PLC AVZ, +8.51% (UK:AVZ)said first-half pretax profit slipped to 119.3 million pounds from 138.1 million pounds. Revenue rose slightly to 581.5 million pounds from 577.1 million pounds. "We have had good profit growth in our Canadian, U.S. institutional and U.K. businesses," Chairman Charles Brady said. "These results have been offset by weakness in the U.S. mutual fund business." Average funds under management were flat at $375.1 billion vs. $374.4 billion. A day after Canadian fund company CI Financial(CA:CIX)said it is considering another bid for Amvescap, which rebuffed a previous offer in July, Amvescap said: "With the appointment of Marty Flanagan as CEO, Amvescap has the right leadership, resources and people to take advantage of... opportunities available globally for an independent company focused solely on investment management." Coach earnings rise 49% on market-share gains (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Coach Inc. COH, +6.26% Tuesday reported that its fourth-quarter net income shot up 49% to $98 million, or 25 cents a share, from $66 million, or 17 cents a share, a year before, citing market-share gains throughout its channels and geographic markets. The Thomsom First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of 24 cents a share. The seller of luxury goods increased its 2006 outlook to earnings of at least $1.24 a share on sales of nearly $2.1 billion. The First Call estimate is for earnings of $1.21 a share. On Monday the company's stock rose 44 cents to $35.55. Coventry Health earnings, sales rise, top forecasts (7:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Managed health care company Coventry Health Care, Inc. CV.H, +0.00% said second-quarter net income rose to $129.5 million, or $1.19 a share, from $84 million, or 93 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter thanks to improving operating fundamentals. Revenue for the period climbed 26.2% to $1.65 billion. The results topped the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of $1.14 a share. Looking ahead, the company said it anticipates third-quarter earnings in the range of $1.20 to $1.22 a share on sales between $1.66 billion and $1.70 billion. Coventry Health sees 2005 revenue between $5.7 billion and $5.8 billion. MAIR Holdings earns decline while rev. rises (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- MAIR Holdings MAIR reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $1.2 million, or 6 cents a share, down from $2.9 million, or 14 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose 8% to $118.4 million from last year's $109.7 million, amid a 6.5% increase in passenger revenue and 25% growth in freight and other revenue. The air carrier's stock closed Monday up 4 cents at $9.08. Qwest Comm. loss narrows, rev. rises (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Qwest Communications International Q, +4.75% reported a second-quarter loss of $164 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. a loss of $776 million, or 43 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, the loss narrowed to 7 cents a share from 18 cents a share. Revenue rose to $3.47 billion from last year's $3.44 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting a loss of 9 cents a share and revenue of $3.44 billion, on average. Debt was reduced to $14.7 billion from $15.5 billion at the same time last year. The telecommunications company's stock closed Monday up 7 cents at $3.89. Masco earnings slip, cuts full-year EPS outlook (7:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Home improvement and building products maker Masco Corp. MAS, -3.56% said second-quarter earnings from continuing operations declined to $274 million, or 64 cents a share, from $294 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Sales for the period climbed 9% to $3.3 billion. The results topped the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 61 cents a share. The company said first-half results were hurt by increases in commodity, energy and freight costs but underlined that second-quarter performance benefited from the strong new construction market as well as an improvement in key retailer sales. Looking ahead, Masco said it anticipates third-quarter earnings in the range of 60 to 64 cents a share and cut its 2005 earnings outlook to "closer to" $2.30 compared to an earlier forecast of $2.40 a share. Sirius Satellite loss widens, ups 2005 subs, sales view (7:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Sirius Satellite Radio SIRI, -2.08% posted a wider second-quarter loss than a year ago but upped its year-end subscriber and revenue guidance. Sirius said it lost $177.5 million, or 13 cents a share, against a year-ago loss of 11 cents, or $136.8 million. Revenue rose to $52.2 million from $13.2 million. Analysts had been looking for a loss of 15 cents a share on revenue of $50.1 million, according to Thomson First Call. It added 365,931 subscribers on a net basis to bring its total to 1.81 million subscribers. Sirius upped its subscriber forecast for the end of the year to 3 million from its previous view of 2.7 million, and sees $225 million in revenue against earlier forecasts of $215 million. Group 1 Auto earnings rise 15% (7:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Group 1 Auto SPI, -6.94% Tuesday reported second-quarter net income net income increased 15% to $18.1 million, or 75 cents a share, from $15.7 million, or 67 cents a share, a year before, citing improved revenue performances throughout the company's business lines. The Thomson First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of 71 cents a share. Revenue rose 20% to $1.58 billion from $1.31 billion. On Monday the company's stock rose 33 cents to $29.37. Green Mountain Coffee's quarterly net rises 13.1% (7:13 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Green Mountain Coffee Roasters Inc. GMCR reported net income of $2.2 million, or 28 cents a share, for the third quarter ended July 2, up from $1.9 million, or 26 cents, earned in the same period in fiscal 2004. Quarterly sales reached $37.8 million, up 20.5% from $31.3 million in the year-ago period. Green Mountain Coffee said it recognized noncash losses of 2 cents and 3 cents a share, respectively, in the fiscal 2005 and fiscal 2004 third quarters, both tied to the company's equity investment in Keurig Inc., which makes single-cup dispensers. The two analysts who follow the company had, on average, been looking for a quarterly profit of 27 cents a share, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Green Mountain Coffee also affirmed its full-year profit outlook range at $1.15 to $1.19 a share, with fourth-quarter earnings pegged at 29 cents to 33 cents a share. In addition, management's looking for sales to grow by 20% to 25% in fiscal 2006, up from the 17% to 21% projected for fiscal 2005. Shares of Green Mountain Coffee added 8 cents to end Monday's trading at $35.25. TRW earns, rev. rise, top expectations (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- TRW Automotive Holdings TRW, -3.33% reported second-quarter earnings of $85 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $76 million, or 75 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 73 cents a share. Revenue rose to $3.37 billion from last year's $3.16 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 37 cents a share and revenue of $3.29 billion, on average. For 2005, the auto parts maker expects earnings excluding non-recurring items of $1.50 to $1.70 a share, vs. analyst estimates of $1.57 a share, and revenue of $12.5 billion to $12.9 billion, vs. analyst projections of $12.62 billion. The stock closed Monday up 25 cents at $26.88. PPL Corp. earns decline, while rev. rises (7:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PPL Corp. PPL, -0.81% reported second-quarter earnings of $128 million, or 67 cents a share, down from $148 million, or 81 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 91 cents a share, which exceeds the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 81 cents. Revenue rose to $1.48 billion from last year's $1.36 billion. The electric utility expects 2005 earnings of $4 to $4.20 a share, surrounding analyst forecasts of $4.11. The stock closed Monday down 21 cents at $61.37. Anadys Pharma quarterly loss narrows, sales jump (6:47 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Biopharmaceutical company Anadys Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ANDS said its second-quarter net loss narrowed to $7 million, or 31 cents a share, from $10.9 million, or 50 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales more than doubled to $581 million from $214 million a year ago. The company said the quarter was highlighted by the signing of a collaboration with Novartis AG NVS, -1.56% (ZZ:001200526), which "dramatically" improves Anadys' financial outlook. Genesee & Wyoming quarterly profit, sales rise (6:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Regional freight railroad operator Genesee & Wyoming, Inc. GWR, -4.05% said second-quarter net income rose to $11.4 million, or 41 cents a share, from $10.8 million, or 39 cents a share, in the year earlier quarter as North American traffic increased. Revenue for the period climbed 25.2% to $92.7 million. Tyco 3rd-quarter net income rose 29%, revenue up 3.3% (6:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tyco International Ltd., TYC, +74.50% the Pembroke, Bermuda, conglomerate, reported fiscal third-quarter net rose 29% on 3.3% higher revenue. For the quarter ended July 1, Tyco's earnings reached $1.19 billion, or 56 cents a share, from $923 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. The latest results reflect special items totaling earnings of 6 cents a share against year-earlier net charges of 2 cents. The consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 49 cents. Revenue reached $10.56 billion from $10.23 billion. Tyco shares rose 35 cents, or 1.2%, on Monday to $30.82. Production, transport costs hit Fresh Del Monte profit (6:10 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc. FDP, +0.07% reported second-quarter net income of $46.5 million, or 80 cents a share, down from $59.4 million, or $1.03 a share, earned in the same period last year. Quarterly sales reached $922.8 million, up 21% from the prior year's $763.6 million, with $90 million of the increase coming from prepared food and the rest from fresh produce. Fresh Del Monte cited higher production and transportation costs in explaining the lower second-quarter profit. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 83 cents a share on revenue of $874 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Fresh Del Monte also restated its 2005 target range calling for a profit of $2.30 to $2.40 a share; Wall Street's average stands at $2.41. Shares of Fresh Del Monte lost 31 cents on Monday, ending at $26. Allied Defense still sees 2005 EPS at $1.48 (6:08 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Defense and security firm Allied Defense Group, Inc. ADG, +0.00% said it still expects to earn $1.48 a share in 2005, with a very weak first half and results accelerating in the second part of the year. Allied Defense Chief Financial Officer Charles Hasper resigned last week. CORRECT: Ryanair profit higher, outlook 'cautious' (3:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Irish low-cost airline Ryanair Holdings PLC RYAAY, -2.21% (UK:RYA)said fiscal first-quarter net profit rose to 69.6 million euros, or 9.1 euro cents, from 53.1 million euros, or 7 euro cents, well above forecasts. Revenue rose 35% to 404.6 million euros, with passenger traffic up 30% to 8.5 million. It said yields rose 3% reflecting the short-haul fuel surcharges imposed by rival European carriers. It added that bookings fell following the bomb attacks in London on July 7 and July 21 and said bookings and yields could be adversely impacted by further attacks. During the quarter, fuel costs rose by 112% to 109.9 million euros. "Our outlook for the remainder of the year is cautious as we continue to budget for higher oil prices," the airline said, "but anticipate that these will be partly offset by a combination of other cost reductions and the current benign yield environment." It maintained its fiscal guidance and still plans to grow traffic by around 27% to 35 million passengers. (Corrects net profit figure.) Tower Semi quarterly loss widens to 71 cents (3:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Independent chip company Tower Semiconductor Ltd. TSEM, -0.59% said the second-quarter net loss widened to $47.2 million, or 71 cents a share, from $36.5 million, or 55 cents a share. Revenue fell to $27.2 million from $33.7 million. Tower expects revenues in the third quarter to be in the range of $20 million to $22 million, reflecting "modest growth" over the second quarter from manufacturing activities. Tower also said it has reached an agreement with its banks under which they will provide the company with up to $30 million of additional funding, to be matched by financing of a further $30 million that will be raised by Tower. Alliance & Leicester: first-half profit down on charge (3:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester PLC(UK:AL)on Tuesday said first-half pre-tax profit fell to 256 million pounds, or 42.1 pence a share, from 306 million pounds, or 47.3 pence a share, in the year-earlier period. The results include a 7 million pound pre-tax accounting loss in 2005 and the comparative for 2004 includes a 52 million pound pre-tax profit on the sale of the bank's merchant acquisition business. Alliance & Leicester said mortgage asset quality remains "excellent" with 0.68% of accounts in arrears at the end of June 2005, the same as at the end of 2004; unsecured personal loan asset quality remains "very strong" with the proportion of balances over 30 days in arrears remaining stable compared to the end of 2004 at 4.2%. "We believe that the first half of 2004 probably represents the best period in the current U.K. personal sector credit cycle, however our credit assessment processes have ensured that our asset quality has remained strong in the first six months of this year," the bank said. Alliance & Leicester said interim dividend rose 7% to 16.8 pence a share. Looking ahead, the bank said it expects total costs for the year to be lower than in 2004. Metro international sales top German, profit rises (3:11 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Retailer Metro AG(DE:725750)on Tuesday for the first time reported more quarterly sales from outside of Germany than from within, and said second-quarter pre-tax earnings rose 10.3% to 227 million euros, or 0.43 euros a share, with sales up 3.6% to 13.83 billion euros. Metro said German business was "subdued" ahead of Bundestag elections, as German sales fell 2.5%, but international growth of 9.9%, with Metro Cash & Carry Eastern Europe sales up 24.9% and Media Markt and Saturn Western European sales up 14.3% offset that decline. EPS came in slightly ahead of forecast with sales slightly below. It held to 2005 goals of 5%-6% sales growth and 8%-12% EPS growth. Continental AG says 4Q break-even not possible in U.S. (2:59 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tires and automotive parts maker Continental AG(DE:543900)said it no longer thinks it will be able to achieve its goal of breaking even in the U.S. in the fourth quarter, after its passenger and light truck tire businesses were "more sluggish" than expected. It assumes that light vehicle production in 2005 will match or "fall just short" of last year. For the year, Continental expects to increase sales and operating profit, and sees a rise in heavy vehicle output in western Europe and the NAFTA trade region, but anticipates truck production in China will be below last year's level. In the second quarter, net profit rose to 252.5 million euros from 131.1 million euros and sales rose to 3.55 billion from 3.17 billion euros. Smiths Group sees in-line fiscal year, upbeat on future (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Smiths Group(UK:SMIN), the British aerospace and medical products group, said it should report in line fiscal year earnings per share before exceptional charges and goodwill amortization, at around 54p, with sales up 11%. It said all four divisions are expected to have achieved double-digit improvements in operating profit. Looking ahead, it said in the sectors important to Smiths, the market outlook remains positive, and recent deals are yielding synergy benefits. Smiths separately announced three acquisitions for 16 million pounds cash, two in the medical area and one in specialty engineering. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Shares of Alpharma Inc. ALO, -4.10% ended Tuesday 52.5% higher after the company reported late Monday earnings of 38 cents a share on revenue of $367.9 million. Excluding special items, earnings would have been 39 cents a share, vs. the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 9 cents a share. Revenue was expected to be $340.3 million. Shares of Aristotle Corp. ARTL, +0.00% surged 12.9% after the maker of educational, health and agricultural products reported second-quarter earnings that rose to $2.6 million, or 15 cents a share from $1.6 million, or 9 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $50.2 million from last year's $44.6 million, due primarily to strength in its educational business. Cash generation improved to $8.1 million from last year's $5.9 million. The stock was last up 83 cents at $7.12. Checkpoint Systems Inc. CKP, +1.03% rocketed 23.4% higher after reporting second-quarter earnings Tuesday of $9.5 million, or 25 cents a share, reversing a $6.4 million, 17 cents a share loss for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $210.4 million from $189.3 million. Excluding restructuring charges, income was 36 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 25 cents a share. See full story. Hong Kong oil and gas company CNOOC Ltd. CEO, -2.57% added 6% after it said it has withdrawn its bid to buy Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% due primarily to the political opposition that followed its bid, which CNOOC called "regrettable and unjustified." CNOOC noted that its $18.5 billion cash bid, which it said was for "purely commercial objectives," represented a $1 billion premium to Chevron's CVX, -1.58% bid for Unocal. The company added that it would have improved its bid, but was held back by the political opposition. Gen-Probe Inc. GPRO, -5.43% tacked on 9.1% after it reported second-quarter net earnings of $13.5 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $11.8 million, or 23 cents a share, last year. Revenue was $72.9 million vs. $61.2 million last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 24 cents a share and revenue of $67.3 million. The medical diagnostics product maker also raised its 2005 revenue forecast to $292 million to $300 million and sees earnings of $1.20 to $1.24 a share, excluding the effect of stock-options expensing. Group 1 Auto shares GPI, -7.19% were driven up 11.4% after the auto seller reported second-quarter earnings of $18.1 million, or 75 cents a share, up from $15.7 million, or 67 cents a share, a year before, and above analyst projections of 71 cents a share. Revenue rose 20% to $1.58 billion from $1.31 billion. The company expects 2005 earnings of $2.95 to $3.02 a share, ahead of analyst forecasts of $2.92 a share. Herbalife HLF, -0.09% rallied 20.7% after the company reported second-quarter earnings that rose to $22.8 million, or 32 cents a share from last year's $12.1 million, or 22 cents a share. The results included a $5.5 million charge related to the moving of its China subsidiary. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 27 cents a share. Revenue rose 19% to $384.7 million. The company raised its 2005 earnings forecast to $1.45 to $1.50 a share. Kinder Morgan Inc. KMI, -1.06% surged 6.9% after it said late Monday that it plans to buy Canada's Terasen Inc. (TER) in a $5.6 billion deal that would expand the Houston-based company's natural-gas and petroleum pipeline operations in North America. See full story. Maxim Integrated Products MXIM, -4.67% gained 8.3% after it reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that rose to 37 cents a share from 36 cents a share in the year-earlier period and matched analyst forecasts. Revenue slipped about 5% to $400.4 million, while bookings rose 7% to $398 million. See full story. Myogen MYOG ran up 21.6% after it said late Monday that it expects top-line results from its ARIES-2 trial, which completed patient enrollment on July 21, by the end of 2005. The company also expects to report top line results from the Phase IIb trial for Darusentan by the end of August. Separately, the company reported a second-quarter loss of $21.5 million, or 60 cents a share, vs. a loss of $13.2 million, or 50 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell to $2.3 million from last year's $2.6 million. PPL Corp. PPL, -0.81% rose 6.1% after it announced a 2-for-1 stock split, raised its quarterly dividend and lifted its long-term earnings growth forecast to 6% to 7% from 3% to 5%. The company also reported second-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items that would have been 91 cents a share topping analyst forecasts of 81 cents. Revenue rose to $1.48 billion from last year's $1.36 billion. See full story. Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, -4.37% advanced 5.3% after saying it narrowed its second-quarter net loss to $21 million, or 4 cents a share, from $426 million, or 91 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding discontinued operations, the company would have broken even on a per share basis, while analysts had been anticipating a loss of 3 cents a share. Revenue for the period declined to $2.42 billion from $2.5 billion a year ago. The company reiterated that the filing of its 10-Q form is likely to be delayed by developments arising out of the previously disclosed investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. See full story. TRW Automotive Holdings TRW, -3.33% hiked up 7% after it reported second-quarter earnings of $85 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $76 million, or 75 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 73 cents a share. Revenue rose to $3.37 billion from last year's $3.16 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 37 cents a share and revenue of $3.29 billion, on average. For 2005, the auto parts maker expects earnings excluding non-recurring items of $1.50 to $1.70 a share, vs. analyst estimates of $1.57 a share, and revenue of $12.5 billion to $12.9 billion, vs. analyst projections of $12.62 billion. Shares of United Therapeutics UTHR, -4.40% climbed 26.3% to after the drugmaker reported better-than-expected second-quarter results. Earnings rose to $12.2 million, or 49 cents a share from $4.1 million, or 18 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and topped the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 33 cents a share. Revenue increased 64% to $30.1 million, topping analyst forecasts of $25.4 million. Deutsche Bank analyst Jennifer Chao followed by raising her stock price target to $68 from $64 on the "blowout" results, and reiterated her buy rating. Decliners AAON Inc. shares AAON, -4.74% ended the session down 11.4% after the air conditioner and heating equipment maker reported second-quarter earnings of $3.1 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share in the year-earlier period, but below analyst forecasts of 30 cents a share, according to an average of 2 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 5.5% to $45.4 million, below one analyst's forecast of $49.5 million. Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. CTB, -3.07% dropped 12.4% after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings of 10 cents to 14 cents a share. Excluding the impact of the Texarkana strike, earnings would be 18 cents to 22 cents a share. Analysts had been projecting earnings of 24 cents a share, on average. For the second quarter, the company reported a loss of $6.88 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to $33 million in net income, or 46 cents a share, for the same period last year. Adjusted earnings would have been 4 cents a share. Revenues fell less than 1% to $509 million, down from $511 million during the same period last year. The Findlay, Ohio-based tire maker was expected to earn 3 cents a share. See full story. Shares of Evolving Systems EVOL, +0.74% dropped 14.7% after the wireless communications software company lowered its 2005 revenue forecast to $40 million to $46 million from $44 million to $50 million. For the second-quarter, company reported a loss of $689,000, or 4 cents a share, wider than the year-earlier loss of $168 million, or a penny a share. Revenue nearly doubled to $9.9 million from $5.3 million in the same period a year ago. Foot Locker FL, -3.78% fell 6.3% after the shoe seller lowered its fiscal second-quarter earnings forecast to 27 to 29 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 35 cents a share, due primarily to disappointing results from its European business. The company said same-store sales for the quarter rose 1.3% and total sales increased to $1.31 billion from last year's $1.27 billion. Read more. Macrovision Corp. MVSN dropped 17.3% after the company cut late Monday its financial outlook for the year, saying the DVD industry "appears to have hit a few road bumps" that will impact its copyright protection business. For the second quarter, the company reported revenue that rose 25% to $44.4 million, but fell short of analyst forecasts of $47.9 million. Earnings fell to 12 cents a share, from last year's 18 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned 16 cents a share, matching analyst estimates. See full story. Shares of Masco Corp. MAS, -3.56% were knocked 5% lower after the home improvement and building products maker said it expects third-quarter earnings of 60 to 64 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 72 cents a share. The company cut its 2005 earnings estimate to "closer to" $2.30 a share from $2.40. For the second-quarter earnings from continuing operations declined to $274 million, or 64 cents a share, from $294 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter, but topped the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 61 cents a share. Sales for the period climbed 9% to $3.3 billion. See full story. Opnet Technologies Inc. OPNT, -0.94% slid 5.1% after it reported late Monday first-quarter revenue of $16.5 million, down from $16.8 million in the year-earlier period, and below the company's prior forecast of $16.6 million to $17.5 million. The loss for the quarter was $454,000, or 2 cents a share, vs. earnings of $2 million, or 10 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and wider than analyst forecasts for a loss of a penny a share. Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% fell 8.4% after the company reported late Monday fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that fell below expectations. The Puerto Rico-based financial services company said it earned $6.4 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $16.9 million, or 67 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 34 cents a share. The company the flattening yield curve narrowed interest spreads, while continued interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve led to higher interest costs. Interest income rose 15% to $48.9 million, while interest expenses grew 49% to $29.6 million. Non-interest income fell 49% to $6.4 million. StarTek Inc SRT, -2.97% shed 13.7% after the company said second-quarter earnings fell to $2.6 million, or 18 cents a share, from $6.5 million, or 44 cents a share, a year ago. Analysts had been expecting average earnings of 24 cents a share from the business process outsourcing company. Revenue dropped 15.9% to $53.2 million following a downturn in supply chain management services and a shift in the company's revenue mix. Tyco International Ltd. TYC, +74.50% lost 9.6% after it said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items, were expected to be 45 to 47 cents a share, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 52 cents a share. For its fiscal third quarter, the diversified industrial conglomerate reported earnings of $1.19 billion, or 56 cents a share, up from $923 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. Excluding special items, earnings would have been 50 cents a share, topping analyst forecasts of 49 cents. Revenue rose $10.56 billion from $10.23 billion, but missed analyst projections of $10.67 billion. See full story. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% fell 9.6% after the company reported late Monday fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that fell below expectations. The Puerto Rico-based financial services company said it earned $6.4 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $16.9 million, or 67 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 34 cents a share. The company the flattening yield curve narrowed interest spreads, while continued interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve led to higher interest costs. Interest income rose 15% to $48.9 million, while interest expenses grew 49% to $29.6 million. Non-interest income fell 49% to $6.4 million. The stock was last down $1.51 at $14.29.
title: Oriental Financial slides as earns fall below forecasts

content: Advancers Shares of Aaron Rents Inc. RNT, -1.08% jumped 14% after the Atlanta specialty retailer of office and residential furniture and appliances reported first-quarter earnings of $18.4 million, or 36 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $12.8 million, or 26 cents a share, and 7 cents better than Wall Street's consensus estimate. The company said all of its businesses showed strong growth in the quarter, and it lifted its earnings outlook for the full year. "At current stock price levels and based upon our future outlook, we also plan to reinitiate our stock buyback program," said Charles Loudermilk, the company's chairman and CEO. Biogen Idec BIIB, -2.53% shares added almost 2% after the company reported first-quarter income of $43.5 million, or 12 cents a share. Last year, it reported a loss of $41.2 million, or 12 cents a share. Revenue was $397.6 million vs. $372.5 million. See full story. Shares of Ciena Corp. CIEN, -2.28% gained 3% after the company was named the preferred supplier for British Telecom's 21st Century Network project. The multi-year deal calls for BT to deploy Ciena's optical switching and transmission and Ethernet transport platforms. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Coca-Cola Enterprises CCE, -2.16% added 3% after the company re-affirmed its outlook for earnings in the low-to-mid $1.30's per share range for the year. GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.56% shares rose 4% after the company said first-quarter profits rose 17% at constant exchange rates to 1.22 billion pounds, or 21.1p a share, with sales rising 3.7% to 5.04 billion pounds, helped by European growth. Glaxo had said earlier this morning that it's on track for low double-digit EPS growth for 2005 after settling with the FDA over manufacturing concerns in Puerto Rico. See full story. Goodrich Corp. GR, +5.88% rallied 5% after the company posted first-quarter net income of $58 million, or 47 cents a share compared with $47 million, or 39 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The aerospace supplier and services company said sales rose 10% to $1.28 billion, due in large part to increased sales for its commercial aerospace aftermarket products. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 40 cents a share on revenue of $1.23 billion. Looking ahead, the Charlotte, N.C. company raised its 2005 outlook, saying it now expects to earn in the range of $1.80 to $1.95 per share versus a prior estimate of $1.60 to $1.80 per share. ImmunoGen IMGN, -3.14% rose 5% after the company received a licensing deal from Genentech DNA, +0.00% ImmunoGen agreed to license its tumor-activated prodrug technologies with therapeutic antibodies Genentech for use with an undisclosed target. Intersil Corp. ISIL shares gained 8% after the Milpitas, Calif., chip maker beat Wall Street's consensus estimate for its first-quarter earnings by a penny and received two upgrades. IVAX Corp. IVX, +14.29% added 7% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $33.5 million, or 12 cents a share, down from $42.3 million, or 16 cents a share in the same period a year ago. The generic drugmaker said a change in accounting increased shares outstanding by 10 million shares. Revenue rose 16% to $491.6 million from last year's $425.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 14 cents a share and revenue of $472 million, on average. The company expects 2005 earnings to be in the middle to upper half of its previously estimated range of 76 to 86 cents a share. Kellogg Co. K, -2.91% shares surged 1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $254.7 million, or 61 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $219.8 million, or 53 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $2.57 billion from $2.39 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 60 cents a share in the March quarter on sales of $2.52 billion. The Battle Creek, Mich., cereal maker also said its board has approved a 10 percent increase in its quarterly dividend, and it forecast earnings at the high end of its previously disclosed range of $2.28 to $2.32 per share. Kulicke & Soffa Industries KLIC, -2.28% shares added almost 1% after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $7.7 million, or 15 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $29.1 million, or 44 cents a share. Revenue fell in the latest three months to $124.8 million from $221.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The latest results include $2 million in severance costs and the reversal of a $378,000 gain on an asset sale. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 14 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $114.5 million. Looking ahead, the Willow Grove, Pa., maker of semiconductor wire bonding assembly equipment said it expects revenue for the June quarter to come in within a range of flat to up 10% from its total for the March quarter. Shares of Multimedia Games MGAM, +0.95% jumped 12% after the Austin, Texas-based maker of gaming equipment reported second-quarter earnings of $5.2 million, or 18 cents a share, on revenue of $40 million, besting Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 11 cents a share on revenue of $39.1 million. Looking ahead, Multimedia Games sees earnings of 10 to 12 cents a share for the third quarter. Northrop Grumman Corp. NOC, -1.03% tacked on 1% after the defense contractor reported first-quarter income from continuing operations of $398 million, or $1.08 a share, compared with $232 million, or 64 cents a share, in the 2004 first quarter. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 91 cents a share and $7.54 billion in revenue. Northrop said revenue rose 4% to $7.5 billion. Northrop also raised its earnings outlook for 2005 to $3.70-$3.85 a share from $3.60-$3.75 a share and said for 2006, earnings will rise on a percentage basis "at a solid double-digit rate." See full story. ON Semiconductor Corp. ONNN rallied 11% after the company swung to a first-quarter profit of $14.8 million, or 4 cents a share. Last year, it posted a loss of $51.8 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue was $302.4 million vs. $308.2 million. Shares of Plexus PLXS, -1.66% added 12% after the Neenah, Wis., provider of electronic manufacturing services posted pro forma earnings of $5.3 million, or 12 cents a share, for the second quarter on revneue of $305.5 million. This performance was 2 cents ahead of the average profit estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company attributed the results to the strength of its diversified customer base and solid execution at all of its operating units. Procter & Gamble Co. PG, -2.37% shares advanced 1% after the Dow component said third-quarter profit rose 13% to $1.72 billion, or 63 cents a share, from $1.53 billion, or 55 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Earnings surpassed analysts' average estimate by 2 cents, according to Thomson First Call. The largest maker of household goods in the U.S. said sales for the quarter advanced 10% to $14.29 billion from $13 billion a year ago, which was ahead of analyst' view for $13.91 billion in sales. As a result of the better-than-expected results, Cincinnati-based P&G raised it full-year earnings target to a range of $2.64 to $2.65 a share, up from its January forecast of $2.61 to $2.64. See full story. Raytheon Co. RTN, -1.78% rose almost 2% after the company reported first-quarter net income of $166 million, or 36 cents a share, up 30% from $128 million, or 30 cents a share, a year before, citing strong results in its government services and defense businesses. The Thomson First Call analysts' estimate was for earnings per share of 33 cents. Quarterly earnings per share from continuing operations were 43 cents, up from 24 cents a year before. The Waltham, Mass. defense contractor's revenue rose 6% to $4.9 billion. The company now expects to have 2005 earnings per share in the $1.85 to $1.95 range. See full story. Scotts Miracle-Gro Co. SMG, -2.87% shares rose 4% after the company said second-quarter earnings grew 14% to $83.3 million, or $2.44 a share, compared to $73.1 million, or $2.21 a share, in the period a year ago. Sales rose 9% in the period to $787.3 million from $723.7 million. The lawn and garden products company cited strong sales of Roundup and lawn services. Sirius Satellite Radio SIRI, -2.08% shares gained 1% after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $193.6 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with a loss of $144 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $43.2 million, from $9.2 million. Sirius Satellite Radio raised its 2005 year-end subscriber estimate to 2.7 million from 2.5 million. The company was expected to lose 15 cents a share and post revenue of $40.5 million, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. See full story. Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -2.85% shares rose 4% after the coffee company reported second-quarter earnings of $101 million, or 24 cents a share, vs. $79 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. See full story. Shares of Wavecom SA WVCM soared 36% after the French wireless communications company posted earnings of 3.1 million euros for the first quarter, better than a year-ago equivalent loss of 14.8 million euros. Looking ahead, the company said gross margins could exceed its target of 33% to 35% in the second quarter Wendy's International Inc. WEN, -3.65% added 3% after the company said first-quarter profit fell to $51.3 million, or 45 cents a share, from $52.8 million, or also 45 cents, in the year-ago period. Revenue for three months ended April 3 rose to $894.2 million from $834.8 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 40 cents a share on revenue of $884 million. For the full-fiscal year, the Dublin, Ohio fast food restaurant operator forecast earnings at $2.29 to $2.35 a share, reflecting the adoption of an accounting change. See full story. Decliners Apache Corp. APA, -1.51% shares fell 1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $559.1 million, or $1.67 a share, up from $344.9 million, or $1.05 a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.66 a share. Revenue rose 45% to $1.66 billion from last year's $1.15 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $1.58 billion. Production rose 7% to an average of 462,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day, while the price the company received for each barrel of oil increased 51% to $46.05. Applebee's International APPB, +0.00% shares lost almost 5% after the restaurant operator forecast earnings of 36 cents to 38 cents a share for the second quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 38 cents a share. Brocade Communications Systems BRCD shares dropped 9% after the company was downgraded by Merrill Lynch to sell from neutral. The firm expects the company to miss consensus earnings expectations for the April quarter by about 2 cents a share. The broker told clients a miss could cause further downward pressure on the stock, even at currently depressed levels. Brush Engineered Materials' BW, -1.83% shares fell 19% after the Cleveland metal products company reported first-quarter earnings of $4.3 million, or 22 cents a share, 3 cents below Wall Street's consensus view. The company said it saw lower margins in the quarter due to an unfavorable product mix, higher copper prices, and lower product levels. Looking ahead, Brush Engineered said the weakness it experienced its two largest markets, telecommunications and computer and automotive electronics, in the latter part of the first quarter has continued into the second quarter, and that it now expects earnings for the year will come in below the $1.30 per share low ened of its previously disclosed profit range. Cabot Microelectronics Corp. CCMP, -3.83% fell 6% after the chip equipment maker reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $6.1 million, or 25 cents a share, down from $9.7 million, or 39 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell 12% to $64.5 million from last year's $73.5 million, below analyst forecasts of $65.6 million, as inventory adjustments have led to continued soft semiconductor industry demand. Shares of DiamondCluster International DTPI sank 15% after the Chicago management consulting services provider forecast earnings of 9 to 10 cents a share in the June quarter on revenue ranging from $52 million to $55 million, below the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. For 2006, the company said it expects earnings of 48 to 54 cents a share, short of Wall Street's consensus estimate of 56 cents. Shares of Estee Lauder Cos. EL, -1.37% lost 8% after the company posted fiscal third-quarter net income of $106.2 million, or 46 cents a share compared with $98.3 million, or 42 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The cosmetics company said sales for the quarter ended March 31 rose 8% to $1.54 billion. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 51 cents a share on sales of $1.52 billion. See full story. Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, -1.86% slid 4% after the Dow component missed Wall Street's consensus estimate for its first-quarter results. See full story. Fleetwood Enterprises FLE, +0.00% dipped 3% after the company said fiscal fourth-quarter sales fell 13% to $555 million from $640 million in the same period a year ago, missing the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $663.3 million, as a 22% drop in recreational vehicle revenue offset a 14% increase in manufactured housing revenue. The company said it still plans to defer distributions on its 6% preferred securities, which would have been due May 15. Shares of Heidrick & Struggles International HSII, -2.72% tumbled 15% after the Chicago provider of executive search and management consulting services posted first-quarter earnings of $6.9 million, or 33 cents a share, a penny ahead of Wall Street's current consensus estimate, but offered a disappointing revenue outlook for the full year. The company sees revenue of $400 million to $412 million for 2005, a performance that would fall short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for revenue of $422.3 million. Intermix Media MIX, +0.18% fell 17% after the company was sued by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer for allegedly being the source of "spyware" and "adware" that has been secretly installed on millions of home computers. The company responded by saying that it does not promote or condone spyware. "Many of the practices being challenged were instituted under prior leadership," the Los Angeles-based company said in a statement, and it has been "voluntarily and proactively improving these applications and related consumer disclosure and functionality for some time." Intermix ceased distribution of the applications at issue earlier this month, it said. The company said it expects to continue its discussions with the Attorney General's Office and still hopes to reach an appropriate and amicable resolution Shares of Inphonic INPC, +1.11% lost 26% after the Washington, D.C., online seller of wireless services posted in-line adjusted earnings for the first quarter but gave a forecast for the second quarter that's below Wall Street's current consensus estimate. The company said it expects adjusted earnings before taxes of 10 to 12 cents a share for June quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 13 cents a share in the period. JDS Uniphase Corp. JDSU shares fell 9% after the company reported a wider third-quarter loss, blaming the higher cost of making its networking gear. See full story. Shares of Kronos KRON sank 21% after the Chelmsford, Mass., provider of workforce management technology forecast earnings of $1.56 to $1.64 a share for fiscal 2005, below the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of $1.71 a share. Marathon Oil MRO, -3.47% shares slid 2% after the company agreed to a deal with Ashland Inc. ASH, -2.01% to acquire Ashland's 38% interest in Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLC and certain other complementary Ashland businesses for total consideration of an estimated $3.7-$3.9 billion. The deal calls for the transfer of $915 million in Marathon stock directly to Ashland shareholders. Ashland shares added 1%. See full story. Shares of Martek Biosciences MATK plummeted 45% after the Columbia, Md., maker of microalgae-based nutritional supplements used in infant formula and fluorescent markers for diagnostic tests lowered its outlook for 2005 due to inventory build-up among its customers. The company expects second-quarter results to be within its prior projections but it anticipates its performance in the third quarter will be hurt by the inventory issues, and unforeseen delays in the international expansion plans of some of its customers due to supply problems. Martek now sees earnings coming in materially below current expectations. It anticipates revenue of $220 million to $240 million for the full year, well short of the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for revenue of $285.6 million. See full story. Microsoft Corp. MSFT, -3.01% dipped nearly 3% ahead of the software giant's quarterly results which are expected after the closing bell. On average, Wall Street analysts expect the world's largest software firm to post fiscal third-quarter earnings before items of 32 cents a share, down from 34 cents a share a year earlier, amid lower interest income following the payout of a massive near $33 billion special dividend in December. Molson Coors Brewing TAP, -2.97% shares dropped 18% after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $46.5 million, or 74 cents a share, on sales of $1.1 billion. Excluding a charge of $40.7 million related to its merger, the Denver-based beer company said that, lost $5.1 million in the March period. The company attributed the loss to lower sales volume in key markets on a year-over-year basis and the merger-related charges. In the same period a year ago, Molson Coors earned $4.8 million, or 13 cents a share, on sales of $924 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 36 cents a share in the March period on sales of $1.25 billion. See full story. MRV Communications MRVC shares fell nearly 40% after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $6.4 million, or 6 cents a share, wider than its loss of $4.8 million, or 5 cents a share, last year. Nabors Industries Ltd NBR, -6.58% slumped 2% after the company reported a record first quarter as its drilling business benefited from sharply higher revenue. See full story. Newell Rubbermaid NWL, -2.94% shares dipped 1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $86.9 million, or 32 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $33.6 million, or 12 cents a share. Excluding items, the Atlanta-based maker of consumer and commercial products earned $50.7 million, or 18 cents a share, in the quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 26 cents a share in the March period. Sales slid 6.5% in the latest three months to $1.39 billion from $1.49 billion in the same period a year earlier. See full story. Novo Nordisk NVO, -1.71% shares fell 12% after the company said its first-quarter net profit rose 17% to $217 million, or 65 cents a share. Operating profit for the period at the Danish pharmaceutical company edged higher by 1%, to $266 million. Operating profit for the full year 2005 is still expected to grow roughly 5%, the company said. Novo Nordisk also said that its European marketing approval application for the use of its NovoSeven product in treating blunt trauma may require additional clinical data. Olympic Steel Inc. ZEUS, -2.19% slipped almost 8% after the company said first-quarter net income fell to $9.6 million, or 92 cents a share, from $10.8 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 52% to $284.6 million from $187 million. The company said tonnage sold decreased 6.6% to 360,000 tons from 385,000 tons a year earlier. Shares of Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% lost 32% after the Puerto Rico-based financial services company earned $13.1 million, or 46 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter ended March 31, down from a year-ago equivalent profit of $16.3 million, or 64 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 68 cents a share in the March period. The company said its net interest margin was hurt by the flattening yield curve and rising borrowing rates in the third quarter. Looking ahead, Oriental Financial said it expects earnings will continue to be lower than its year-ago performances for the next several quarters. The company was hit with downgrades from Piper Jaffray and Keefe, Bruyette in the wake of the news. Shares of Ralcorp Holdings RAH fell 21% after the St. Louis food products maker reported second-quarter earnings of $17.9 million, or 59 cents a share, a dime below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose slightly in the latest three months to $386.6 million from $383.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, -0.57% dropped 15% after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $1.04 billion as it took massive charges and saw weakness in its computing business. See full story. Shares of Serologicals SERO fell 16% after the Atlanta developer of biological research products reported a first-quarter pro forma profit of $4.3 million, or 13 cents a share, a nickel short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company said results were hurt by an unfavorable product mix and a revenue shortfall related to the timing of certain customer deliveries. Skechers USA SKX, -2.08% shares dropped 7% after the Manhattan Beach, Calif., footwear maker posted an in-line profit for the first quarter and offered a disappointing outlook for the second quarter. The company forecast earnings of 21 to 26 cents a share on sales of between $245 million and $255 million for the June period, below the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 28 cents a share on $259.9 million. Stanley Works SWK, -1.91% lost 7% after the company reported its first-quarter profit declined from a year ago when it took a one-time credit relating to the sale of its residential door business. See full story. Tweeter Home Entertainment TWTR, -3.34% shares gave back more than 18% after the company said its second-quarter loss was $27.4 million, or $1.11 a share. A year earlier the company had a loss of $4.6 million, or 19 cents a share. The company attributed the wider loss to special charges related to deferred tax assets. Without the charges, the company took a second-quarter loss per share of 20 cents. The Thomson First Call analysts' consensus estimate was for a loss per share of 10 cents. The Canton, Mass. specialty electronics retailer's revenue was $184.7 million, down 1% from $185.8 million a year before, while same-store sales dropped 4%. The retailer also announced plans to close 19 stores and reduce its staff by 6%. Shares of Tyler Technologies TYL, -3.14% fell 27% after the Dallas developer of information management technology products reported first-quarter earnings of $470,000, or a penny per share, down from a year-ago profit of $2.1 million, or a nickel per share. Revenue fell 2% in the latest three months to $40.7 million from $41.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Wall Street's consensus estimate for the March period was for a profit of a nickel per share. Tyler Tech also disclosed the consolidation of certain senior management positions and named Brian Miller chief financial officer. The company forecast earnings of 2 to 4 cents a share for the first half. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 7 cents a share in the second quarter. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% dropped almost 27% to $15.90 in morning action, making the stock the top percentage decliner on the New York Stock Exchange. After Wednesday's closing bell, the Puerto Rico-based financial services company earned $13.1 million, or 46 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter ended March 31, down from a year-ago equivalent profit of $16.3 million, or 64 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 68 cents a share in the March period. The company said its net interest margin was hurt by the flattening yield curve and rising borrowing rates in the third quarter. Looking ahead, Oriental Financial said it expects earnings will continue to be lower than its year-ago performances for the next several quarters. The company was hit with downgrades from Piper Jaffray and Keefe, Bruyette in the wake of the news.
title: Oriental Financial tops NYSE % decliners list

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oriental Financial Group OFG, +1.44% said Thursday that it has named Mari Carmen Aponte and Jose Gil de Lamadrid Jimenez as directors. Aponte will work on the San Juan, Puerto Rico-based company's compensation committee and de Lamadrid will be on its audit committee.
title: Oriental Financial Group appoints two new directors

content: Sipex Corp might restate 2004, quarterly 2003 results (6:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sipex Corp. SIPX said late Thursday that it might restate its financial statements for fiscal 2003 and the first, second, and third quarters of 2004. The company said the potential restatement is due to the possible improper recognition of revenue on sales for which price protection, stock rotation and/or return rights may have been granted. As a result of the timing of the audit committee's investigation, Sipex said it will delay the announcement of its financial results for the fourth quarter and fiscal 2004, and may delay the timely filing of its Form 10-K with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
